185043499.review:
Here is the picture: If you are looking for a slow, repetitive, chill out, console game with very light survival/building elements, then this is for you.
Its valid. It has enough content to hold your interest for a couple of hundred hours.

For everyone else: This game is basically what the console port tech demo would be for any major base constructing and survival game on the market.
It has a bit of everything, from base building to space dog fighting, and at the same time nothing at all cause everything you will find in it is a scaled down lite version of the specific genre.

Space fighting is holding a button to make your ship auto target/turn towards the enemy while you hold M1, and base building is a nothing burger cause you dont really need any of it unless you want to create a larger plant farm or a mine, then your later freighter replaces everything anyway cause it acts as a mobile base.

Yet the largest downsides for me were:
- There are no invasions of any kind that would prompt you to defend your base, every enemy in the game is an annoyance instead of a challenge.
- Multiplayer is completely unsupported and bugged. You can meet eachother, you can play alongside, but there are a myriad problems with it. Players desync from eachother constantly, one flattens the terrain, the other one cant see it being changed. One opens a door and the other can no longer walk through it because its permanently stuck for them. There is night for one player while there is day for the other. Etc.

Basically no matter what you do, the game will try to "mix and match" between two or more individual save files depending on how many players are present.
Its a complete mess.

I can see this as Timmy's first experience with open world survival games and its not a bad take per say, but its lite.
Its the definition of lite.
Its a console PG/lite version of everything that is going on in the PC market.
Its dreadfully too little at least to my taste.

Если вы любите собирательство и бесконечное брожение, то эта игра для вас)
А вообще я сломался на моменте, когда понял, что закончился  дигидроген. При этом большинство элементов уже добывались в промышленных масштабах в автоматическом режиме.
Графика приятная, интересно посмотреть на красочные виды разных планет и погодных условий. Особенно интересно погулять по творениям (базам) игроков, там есть на что посмотреть.
Технологии развития откровенно расстроили, потому что нисколько не упрощают виртуальную жизнь и не уменьшают количество беготни.
Достаточно быстро понимаешь, что все задания строятся на одних и тех же механиках и в них нет развития/усложнения. Накопив достаточное количество ресурсов/модов, "море становится по колено" и копить дальше ресурсы/кредиты и далее по списку становится незачем. Поэтому наиграв 120 часов, благополучно удалил игру.
Ах да, сюжет: его основная нагрузка скрасить обучения механикам и дать новые чертежи. Основной сюжет серый и невнятный, особенно в текстовой подаче, короче он там есть.

A wonderful game that's gone through a long, arduous journey to become what it is now, No Man's Sky continues to be a game I return to every update. While I will admit, the systems are shallow, there's enough things to do to keep you busy. Once you get tired with one thing, there's always the next thing to do, and the next after that. Everyone who plays this game has their own preferred way of playing this game, from trading to piracy to discovering fauna. In its current state, I can't recommend it enough. Just don't go in expecting the game to guide you on a marked path. This is the sort of sandbox where you make your own fun.

I should mention: The game goes on sale periodically, so if you're on the fence at the current price, then it's worth waiting a bit for the sale.

__________________________________________________________
игру рекомендую, в ней можно очень много чего сделать, а именно:
1. заниматься торговлей
2. исследовать планеты (иногда попадаются очень красивые пейзажи)
3. гриндить ресурсы, но это долго и на любителя
4. коллекционировать корабли, мультитулы, прокачивать снаряжение
5.построить базу, завести инопланетного питомца
и много чего ещё! поэтому ставлю игре палец вверх.
а вот в следующем разочаровала игра (довольно сильно во втором минусе) :
1. сюжет.
И не поймите меня неправильно, сюжет-то интересный! Но основная сюжетная ветка в начале игры прям гриндом душит. Я прошёл половину пути, потом когда наиграл уже 16 часов забил просто на сюжет и занимался чем хочу до 48-49 часов. Это не огромный недостаток, но многих людей может оттолкнуть!
2. опять проблема с сюжетом.
И когда я минуток 20 так назад сидел и делал квест по достижению к центру галактики, мне было написано: "соберите глифы атласа, глиф какой-то там из чего-то"
я же внимания не обратил, получил половину глифов просто летая и достиг другой галактики.
Оййй, что дальше было...
[h3]Дальше спойлеры! Читайте на свой страх и риск[/h3]
[spoiler] и вот в новой галактике я оказался с поломанным всем чем только можно было. Вы задаётесь вопросом, а почему же это минус? корабль же хоть долго, но быстро чинить!
А вот тут нет. У меня был корабль стражей. Пришлось вызвать начальный звездолёт, хорошо что я его держал у себя.
Но это ладно, нагриндил бы я потом... Проблема в другом.
ДЛЯ ВЫПОЛНЕНИЯ КВЕСТА НУЖНЫ БЫЛИ ВСЕ ГЛИФЫ!!)))))))))))))))))))) ЛОЛ КЕК ЧЕБУРЕК
ладно, подумал я. сделал телепорт, тепнулся на базу рядом с порталом... А портала там не было. Исчез, прихватив с собой кусок ландшафта.
И тут я обомлел от ужаса и осознания того, что мне придётся искать новый портал, гриндить ресурсы для корабля стражей, потом искать глифы эти и лететь обратно в новую галактику для продолжения (или конца) сюжетной линии?
АААААААААААААААААААА
Тут ещё повезло, что один добрый человек (сейчас без сарказма я говорю) нашёл портал прям близко к центру галактики и лететь долго не придётся. Но о Боже, тут же гринда часов на 5-10!!![/spoiler]
Из-за этого я отрицательную оценку ставить игре не буду - ведь принесла-то она мне больше положительных эмоций, чем негативных! Но это проблема, конечно...
ИТОГ
Игра хорошая, рекомендую вам купить по скидке, со своим спокойным и неторопливым геймплеем оказалась одна из самых увлекательных игр в которые я играл в последнее время. И может кто-нибудь в комментариях подсказать, как эффективнее решить проблему с сюжетом?
А, ну и да, это мой первый обзор!! Всем хорошего дня кто прочитал (или спокойной ночи)!

184988900.review:
I didn't think I'd like No Man's Sky this much! The game just pulls you in like a black hole — you sit down, "time flies," and suddenly it's night. The map isn't just planets; it's entire universes! So many worlds, each unique in its own way. Even though you're flying through the same galaxies, there's always something new on each planet.

The graphics are stunning — the colors, textures, atmosphere — it looks like you're traveling through a living painting. Mountains, oceans, alien plants, landscapes — every new world is like a little piece of art.

And yes, the game really pulls you in. At first, you might think, "Oh, it's just a space simulator," but nope, you’ll get hooked. Earning upgrades for your ship, searching for rare resources, and discovering new technologies... it’s all super engaging!

Sometimes the optimization can be a bit off, but it's not a deal-breaker. And honestly, even though the game isn't new, the developers have been doing a great job of supporting it — adding new events, updates, and improvements. In that regard, they're doing an excellent job.

So, if you enjoy exploring, building, and soaking in beautiful views, No Man's Sky is definitely for you.

And if you haven't tried it yet, get ready to lose a few weeks to space exploration! It’s even more fun with friends — you can fly around planets, build bases, and have some epic space races!

this game has got free updates and is still a boring piece of garbage.

edit: this is a conclusion, its not like i can share all my thought proccess, but I can say that I was there in 2016 when this game launched. I played it a lot on ps4. 

It really hasnt changed much - the gameplay is very repetitive - players who play this every other weekend do so either because of :

1- SUNK COST FALLACY (they spent so much time learning about the mechanics and secrets etc that they believe itll be a waste to drop the game)

2- UPGRADE LOOP (getting the best ships frighters weapons etc just for the thrill of upgrade, only to create another save file and do it all over again - one of the main reasons they came up w expeditions -)

The base building is very very limited. You can decorate a lot of stuff, but you cant really USE that stuff. Its a doll house basically

Last thing - i call people who talk about redemption losers, because they deserve nothing more than contempt. You see all these youtubers who have no clue of anything, make videos about NMS and how it redeemed itself. Its all BS. They just want to promote the thought that game devs should not abandon a game and deliver good things - what people paid for - instead of scams. You, as a new player, will only enjoy it if you like UPGRADE LOOPS, but there are better games for that out there.

Игра далеко не для всех. Большая часть игрового комьюнити должна пропустить эту игру мимо, ибо никакого экшена и крутого сюжета тут нема. Майнквест интересный, но только в виде истории, сам по себе геймплей в квесте - принеси да подай, а потом прочитай кусок истории.

마크 마냥 시드도 많고 건축, 커스텀, 온라인 사람들이랑 하는 원정 탐험 등등 생각해보면 할게 아직도 많지만 아직 탐험 밖에 못해보고 있다.... 
왜냐? 이거만 해도 재밌으니까 혼자 행성 다니면서 스캔만 해도 매번 다른 생태계에 구경하는 맛도 있다.
 간혹 내 자신이 압도되는 행성도 있고 우주선 내부 고증, NPC간 대화, 상호작용등등 몇몇 구조물간 버그 말고는 단 한번의 버그도 경험하지 못했다.
 스타시티즌, 스타필드등등 다른게임도 있지만 이건 캐주얼하게 나오면서 지킬만한 고증은 다 잘 지킨 게임이다. 
이거 때문에 로스트아크 숙제를 까먹은적도 있다

I finally gave in to all the people saying how much better this game is now and how great it is.

All the star systems are caricatures of what actual systems would be like, i have not seen a forest or a mountain or a river in the game, i have found no gas giants, all star systems are pretty much the same both in terms of rough number of planets and and what those planets look like. 184938030.review:
[h1]My NMS Review[/h1]
I'm going to be as honest as I can with this review. 

I haven't been very active with this game since I first got it, mostly due to hardware limitations for myself at the time, but recently, I have been able to play it in a stable manner.

From what I've seen, here are my thoughts on different aspects of the game.

[h2]Mainline story[/h2]
Mainline story felt very quick for me and somewhat sort of, "huh alright". Granted, I had come from a save after the liquidators expedition, so I was pretty heavily stacked resource wise so when I finally was allowed to progress the main story, I basically could reach anywhere I wanted.

Story itself is alright. It's an interesting dive into the psychology of living in a simulation, but seems to leave a lot for you to interpret for yourself, which for a game like No Man's Sky, I think makes the most sense. I think for a game like No Man's Sky, the stories we make instead become more important than the actual overarching story of realizing the simulation needs to be reset.

[h2]Expeditions[/h2]
I have fully completed only one expedition, being the liquidators expedition, but from my experience, I genuinely enjoyed it a lot. Seeing everyone run around and do their own thing, and use in-game mechanics 
like save beacons to help others easily find places, genuinely made it feel fun to play.

Also, having older ones repeat is amazing for people who couldn't be there. I am extremely tired of games locking what is in essence, seasonal content, away forever because you weren't there for it. I didn't even realize it at the time, but the expedition I was playing was a repeat one, and asking around, it seems older ones get repeated every so often. This is a great system and should stay this way. You have no idea how much it frustrates me when games lock away content forever because "You weren't there at the time so too bad".

[h2]Settlements[/h2]
They leave more to be desired. Do they work? Yes, they do, but they sorta feel like they stagnate at some point and you're just left waiting for something to happen. Maybe some system to allow us to upgrade existing building further would be nice, as it would provide more to do regarding settlements. I see more potential with settlements if they are ever expanded upon, maybe some way for planets with multiple settlements to receive help from other players, or some system to prestige a settlement once it reaches max level, with some special reward for doing so.

[h2]Post-game[/h2]
I am still somewhat within the post-game as of writing this and I genuinely think it's fun to realize there's so much more out there to see. The introduction of the 4th hidden race, the Authophages, genuinely has me excited for more post-game content they add to No Man's Sky. My only concern being, that people may rush to see that new content if it's locked behind beating the main-line story first, but that ultimately is their choice.

[h2]Freighters[/h2]
I really like these in-game. Having the ability to call a massive ship to easily access my resources feels so nice for base-building. My only complaint with freighters is the modules can sometimes feel like a pain to find, but I may just be unlucky.

[h3]Freighter Interior Bases[/h3]
This is honestly really well done, it's super seamless to make bases within the freighter. I only have 2 complaints regarding it though, it's hard to tell if a room is powered sometimes, because stairs do not transfer power between floors from my understanding, and collecting farm output takes a while. I hope the farming side of it, is updated to allow for a single button to harvest all connected plant rooms, to save me time and rooms illustrate if they are lacking power, but other than that, a really good system for a base on the go.

[h2]Crafting[/h2]
I do not want to say too much on refining since I have barely scratched the surface, but one way I could see to improve it is to have some way to learn missing recipes within the game. Maybe have a vendor who trades nanites for recipes you don't have yet, or something else since slamming ingredients in to hopefully have something happen can become tiring. Other than that, cool system

[h2]Starships[/h2]
Oh man, these are really good. Being able to assemble them yourself instead of gambling for eons on normal starships having a setup you want, is great. Sentinel starships don't really follow this system, but I honestly think it fits better, given you can't extract their individual components anyways. My only suggestion for improvement would be to add a scrapping dock within your freighter, so you can scrap starships you find on the go far easier

[h2]Planets[/h2]
Man some of these get funny. There is so much variety in planets, you never know what you can expect. I've stumbled onto planets I wasn't even looking for, like a 99.5% perfect planet, or a planet that has bubbles everywhere for no reason. If you like asking yourself "What is going on here" you'll like the planets in this game.

[h2]Exocrafts[/h2]
These are just fun, nothing else to add.

[h2]Base-Building[/h2]
Feels very fleshed out, but my only complaint being I wish there were more power generation components like a nuclear reactor. Other than that, works very well and genuinely is fun to see what crazy things people have made.

[h2]Autophages[/h2]
Yes, I'm giving them their own section. I want more of these guys post-game and expanded further. They add a lot more to the game for me and I want to see more from them story-wise. Staff creation is so cool, but being forced to gamble on the right colors your want can feel like a pain.

[h2]Space Stations[/h2]
Space stations are great and simple to understand what you want and where to get it from. However, I have stumbled across abandoned ones and I always have had the thought "I wish I could own this station". I am really hoping more on these stations is considered in the future for players to take them over to make their own economy in a system they can call their own.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The game still leaves more to be desired, but that isn't an inherently bad thing. 

This game has so much to offer and the things I did try, I honestly tended to like and want more of. 

There is probably more I didn't cover in this review and I may update it if I can, but I highly recommend this game if you're looking for something new to try.

184925663.review:
Buy on-sale.

I once bought the game back in 2020 or so and refunded it because the beginning was agonizingly slow and it bored me to tears with the amount of steps and maintenance everything took, and after being gifted the game and playing it again, *that has not changed.*

The core experience of the game (seemingly) hasn't changed since launch; That being, exploring new worlds in a vast universe. The stuff they've added is pretty great and all, but you could watch a video from 2016 and see the same game.

Reaching the core of the galaxy is still the biggest disappointment. It's implied you can return to the Atlas to make a decision again, but instead, you're thrown into the next galaxy. I would've hoped that this had changed since release, but it hasn't.

Combat on the ground is passable at best, and ship combat is absolutely awful. Your auto-lock doesn't rotate your ship fast enough, so you endlessly backflip trying to catch whatever pirate or sentinel ship is attacking you. You could take the fight to a planet's atmosphere to remove that third dimension somewhat, but it's very much possible to get accosted by pirates while you're nowhere near a planet, moon or station.

Regardless, I've still found enjoyment. Finding abandoned ships to claim and scrap or repair, poking around for good multitools, going on the hunt for good freighters, building and upgrading my bases of operations; It's nice to sit down, put on a podcast and just let the grind flow for a couple of hours.

But my biggest criticism still remains: The core of the game has not changed, it's only been pasted over. And I find that to be just as disappointing as it was to witness through videos in 2016.

I never thought I will buy this game when I first heard of the bad launch when it first came out but this turned out to be one of the most fun games I played in a while. 

Hello Games took their word in and bought back most of their promises so far in the updates that came prior when I started playing. Including seeing other players in MP. 

There are a few issues since they often add the update and not tweak it or amplify it later (most infamously, the terrain regeneration and limitations of terraforming for bases), but the overall experience is still fun. It seems that most of the limitations you have to compromise with is because they have to make it compatible in other platforms including console which has a lot more limitations than PC. 

At the end of the day if you hate Eve Online with how its MMO style and like cultivation/resource gathering games, this is the game for you.

184904287.review:
Had a lot of fun from beginning to end except for the absolutely disgusting, restrictive and infuriating base building (without glitching which is reserved for a minority of players who want/have the time to put into learning that I guess). Parts don't snap together when they have to, placement makes no sense, sometimes you even have to find a very specific pixel floating with free view while maintaining surgical precision with your mouse/controller to be able to place a floorboard next to another in the 2nd floor of a building.

If you want to place a stair leading to the 2nd floor of your house and the game doesn't want to snap it to the correct block and doesn't want to show you anything to attach it to, then good luck with it since "free placement" is not free at all because you have no real control over it and it's just as bad (if not worse designed) to build with. Building parts go underground for no reason even when highlighted in the "correct" position and stay there unless you dig and remove them (making snap even worse with wrong anchor points). Terrain modification resets and bugs out (so goodbye basement/cave building). This was easily the worst base building experience I've ever had in any game I tried, it's truly terrible and poorly executed without having to resort to glitches to fix the lack of flexibility and abominable grid this game has when it comes to it.

That being said, if you are ok with wasting hours of your day trying to fit a single furniture into your base or are ok learning how to glitch the items then you can build some crazy good, beautiful stuff. Props to the creators who have the patience/tools/time to deal with that. Was it worth it for me with how frustrating and clunky it is? No.

Other than that, if you don't care about base building (which was the main appeal to me) then the game has a lot of other things to it that are fun and worth getting it for, to play it at least once. It's quite unique and very fun.

6/10 because base building is terrible. Hoping they improve it (I'm still playing)

184878639.review: I've been playing this game for years and I've always recommended it to other people. It's one of my favorite games to play ever. The graphics are stunning and the game play is great. But the sound track is just perfection, there's just something great about it that I can't seem to put my finger on. I know Hello Games isn't making this game their top priority anymore which is sad to me, because this game still has a lot of potential. If i had to update it i'd put more immersive space battles. Like how if you blow up a freighter near a planet, the debris can fall through the atmosphere and actually land on the planet for players to explore even more once they've taken it down and it won't despawn. I just would like the game's battle aspect to be improved on because it could be really cool. Another idea could be like from the game Helldivers 2 where you can call down missile strikes and such from your freighter, i feel like that could easily be added to the game, if your freighter is close enough to a planet you could send down orbital barrages or something similar. Also, I think it would be interesting if we could build our own space station orbiting around a planet as a base. I know the freighters kind of sub as a personal space station but I still think it would be cool to build your own orbital space station around a planet. You wouldn't be able to move to other systems, it would just orbit the planet you built it by. I have Plenty of more ideas but I think you get the point, the game still has so much more potential and could reach many other fan bases, that seems like untapped potential to me, not to mention a good money grab.

184858384.review:
"Космическая сказка с элементами выживания (и разочарования!)"

Когда я впервые запустил No Man's Sky меня встретило что-то между абсолютным восторгом и панической атакой. Космос! Миллиарды планет! Я сам себе капитан Кирк! Но через минуту восторг немного ослаб — мой многострадальный шаттл дымился как старый чайник, а в инвентаре лежала только горсть углерода и какой-то странный болт с пометкой "сломано".  

Ну ладно, думаю, чинить так чинить. Тут-то и началось самое весёлое. **No Man's Sky** — это не просто игра, это тренажёр по выживанию для тех, кто не боится собирать 50 тонн феррита, чтобы потом осознать, что тебе нужен не феррит, а высокоочищенный феррит. И, конечно, крафтить его ты будешь на другом конце планеты, куда лететь полчаса.  

Но как только ты залатаешь свой корабль и сорвёшься в гиперпространство, начнётся настоящий космический трип. Вот ты исследуешь радиоактивную планету, где растут светящиеся грибы размером с дом. Вот ты нашёл планету с идеально бирюзовыми океанами, над которыми летают динозавры. А вот на тебя напал пиратский флот, и ты впал в панику, пытаясь вспомнить, на какой кнопке у тебя стоят фотонные пушки (они, кстати, на X, не забудь).  

Игра полна мелких нюансов, которые заставляют любить её или ненавидеть. Вот пример: хочешь построить базу? Никаких проблем! Правда, через час ты поймёшь, что забыл провести проводку к солнечной панели, и твой новый космический "домик у озера" превратится в мрачный барак.  

Но самое крутое в No Man's Sky — это её масштаб. Здесь реально миллиарды планет. Ты можешь стать исследователем, торговцем, пиратом или просто тем чуваком, который собирает яйца чужих и потом убегает от орды злых ксеноморфов.  

Да, иногда игра может быть утомительной. Инвентарь — это адская головоломка, где каждое свободное место — сокровище. А интерфейс заставляет тебя задуматься, почему ты вообще решил полететь в космос без инженерного образования.  

Но всё это забывается, когда ты стоишь на краю нового мира, смотришь на закат двух солнц и понимаешь: это не просто игра, это целая вселенная, где ты — её часть.  

Плюсы:
+ Бесконечный космос для исследования.  
+ Уникальные планеты и биомы.  
+ Возможность построить базу своей мечты (ну, или кошмара).  

Минусы:
- Иногда хочется выкинуть инвентарь в ближайшую чёрную дыру.  
- Некоторые механики требуют терпения святого.  

Если ты готов к приключениям, где красота и хаос идут рука об руку, садись в свой шаттл, запасайся ферритом и отправляйся к звёздам. Увидимся в космосе, путешественник!

184821117.review:
Die Frage ist nicht, ob das Spiel gut oder schlecht ist, sondern ob ich es empfehlen würde oder nicht.. 
Und auch dann würde ich eher sagen "kommt darauf an..."

Ich hatte einige kleinere Bugs, aber nicht in dem Maße, wie es andere berichtet haben, Performance-Probleme habe ich auch nicht... Ich spiele nur SinglePlayer, was vielleicht auch nochmal einen großen Unterschied ausmacht. 
Der Grund, weshalb ich dieses Spiel nicht empfehlen kann, ist die Eintönigkeit nach einigen Stunden Spielzeit. Mein größter Kritikpunkt ist [i]"Es fühlt sich einfach alles gleich an..."[/i]

Viele schreiben, dass man so unendlich viel entdecken kann.. Das ist gefühlt in den ersten Stunden auch so. Jeder Planet sieht anders aus, andere Pflanzen, Tiere, Biome...

Aber nach ein paar Stunden merkt man dann:
- Man landet auf einem roten Planeten mit hohen Temperaturen
- Die Lebenserhaltung tickt langsam runter, während man Pflanzen und Mineralien abbaut. Dafür bekommt man Eisen, Kohlenstoff, Sauerstoff, Kobalt, ... 
- Ein paar Tiere laufen durchs Bild, manchmal sind sie aggressiv, meistens aber nicht, "gefährliche Flora" steht überall rum und man bekommt Schaden, wenn man nicht aufpasst
- Man findet eine Höhle, aber außer ein paar Mineralien und "gefährlicher Flora" findet man dort auch nichts besonderes
- Man findet einen Außenposten, in dem 2 Außerirdische sitzen (mit einem beginnt ein Dialog, bei dem man evtl. etwas erhält, der andere verkauft Upgrades)
- Ein Sturm zieht auf, die Lebenserhaltung tickt schneller runter, man gräbt sich irgendwo ein und wartet bis der Sturm vorbei ist, oder geht zu seinem Raumschiff zurück

Nun kann man oben in der Beschreibung die Farbe des Planeten 1:1 austauschen mit ein paar anderen Farben und anderen Umweltfaktoren (blau und kalt, grün und toxisch, gelb und verstrahlt)... Auch wenn die Pflanzen anders aussehen, fühlen sich fast alle Planeten exakt gleich an. Das fällt mit höherer Spielzeit immer mehr auf, so dass man irgendwann gar nicht mehr versucht, Planeten zu erkunden. Alle Gebäude sind gleich, alle Pflanzen/Mineralien liefern die gleichen Ressourcen und ob man auf einem kalten oder heißen Planeten spielt, macht bis auf die Farbe keinen fühlbaren Unterschied.

Im gesamten Universion um Milliarden von Systemen gibt es genau 3 verschiedene Spezies, die von ihrem Charakter unterschiedlich sein sollen. Spielerisch spürt man hier aber nichts. Mir ist schon klar, dass es vom technischen Hintergrund hier nicht so viele Möglichkeiten gibt, aber bestärkt nur meinen Kritikpunkt.
Es gibt eine fixe Anzahl an unterschiedlichen Gebäudetypen, die immer gleich aussehen und immer die selben Optionen bieten. Die Nebenmissionen sind immer die gleichen, die Dialoge usw. Und selbst die Hauptmission wird eigentlich nur damit gestreckt, dass man unterschiedliche Planeten besuchen muss, um dort wieder nur ein bestimmtes Gebäude zu finden. Ansehen hat nicht wirklich einen Einfluss auf das Gameplay.
Ich habe noch kein lebendiges Schiff, was ich mir auf jeden Fall noch holen werde.. Aber auch die Raumschiffe fühlen sich ziemlich gleich an, wobei ich es hier noch am coolsten finde, sich ein hübsches rauszusuchen, mit dem man dann später rumfliegen will...

Nach einiger Spielzeit aber sucht man sich speziell nur noch ein paar Planeten für ein paar spezielle Ressourcen raus und farmt die ab. Man interessiert sich nicht mehr, da es nichts zu sehen gibt. In den ersten Stunden sieht man noch ein paar Highlights, wenn man spezielle Planeten besucht. Aber irgendwann hat man auch hier alles gesehen. Man spielt effizienter und damit grindet man sich nur noch durch das Spiel um am Ende welches Ziel zu haben?

Paar Tipps am Rande:
[spoiler]
- Naniten bekommt man wesentlich schneller, indem man sich 2 Vorkommen "unkontrollierter Schimmel" (die Bälle, kein Pilzschimmel) sucht, bei beiden einen Außenposten erstellt und per Teleporter hin und her switcht, um diese abzubauen. Dann kann man sie im Verhältnis 5:1 in Naniten umwandeln (Hab auf meinem Frachter aktuell 24 Raffinerien). Damit kann man dann seine Ausrüstung schnell pimpen.
- Man teleportiert sich 1x komplett durch die besuchte Stations-Liste und nimmt alle Missionen an mit Wächter/Tiere töten/füttern. Dann landet man auf einem Planeten und führt diese aus. Man kann so in sehr kurzer Zeit extrem viele Missionen erledigen, was für einen höheren Status bei den Gilden führt
- Man kommt an den Punkt, an dem man von den Gilden Items erhält, um neue Plätze freizuschalten (Exo, Raumschiff, Werkzeug, Frachter). Man sucht sich 2 Systeme raus und switcht ständig hin und her und holt sich so alle Updates, die man benötigt. Zusätzlich erhält man noch ein paar andere kostenlose Items, die man auch verkaufen kann
- Auf Planeten mit Dissonanz hackt man eine Wächtersäule, so dass alle Drohnen ausfallen. Dann kann man ungestört alle Dissonanzresonatoren mit dem Schiff abfarmen und erhält ne Menge gutes Zeugs, mit denen man dann auch Wächter finden kann. Diese kann man sehr gut verkaufen, so dass man sich eigentlich keine Sorgen mehr um Units machen muss.
- Piratenfrachter sind sehr einfach zu bekommen/zerstören, indem man zu Beginn die Antriebe zerstört, damit der Frachter nicht abhaun kann. Danach die Frachter-Kanonen ausschalten. Wird die Zivile Flotte vorher zerstört, erhält man sogar ein S Frachter-Modul (also bei mir bisher in allen Fällen: Flotte gerettet: Units/Nanit, Flotte verloren: Frachter Modul)
[/spoiler]

So habe ich also jetzt alles auf maximale Größe/Qualität aufgerüstet und fliege in Richtung Herz der Galaxie um dort in die nächste Galaxie zu wechseln, die sich wieder 1:1 genau so anfühlt...

184795934.review:
VR Review:  Mostly
PC: also
Steam Deck: also

TLDR: WTF are you still reading for?  Get out there and scan!

Normal PC Mode: Not only has the game come incredible distances since launch it STILL keeps getting better.  I'm excited to put in a real play-through finally that i'm hoping to do mixed in VR and on my PC and my Steam Deck

Steam Deck: Awesome.  Really blown away by how good it runs on the deck.  Totally native settings run and look great on mine.

VR:   Overall this is my legit favorite experience i've had in VR so far.  I can't wait to feel better so hopefully i can go again another hour or two tonight.  It feels natural and very immersive and i'm playing 100% in my office chair just backed up from my desk a little bit.

Performance: Wow! After configuring it to match my video card (DLSS instead of FSR) it runs INCREDIBLY well via wireless Steam Link to my Quest 3.  Buttery smooth at all times wether running around, scanning, fighting, or flying like a drunk monkey.  (I7 9700 w/4070ti)

Controls: I switched from teleport to smooth movement based on shoulders(body position) and smooth turning and it is an absolute JOY to play in VR.  The controls all felt natural and right.  You grab your gun/multi tool from your right shoulder and use it like a real one, selecting it's mode on the back of the gun itself.

The menus on your left wrist and you actually grab the plants etc you would normally pickup and you pull them out with your off hand.  

You select a switch to the side of your goggles to switch to Scanning mode and back.  It's very cool IMHO.

VR Sickness: I was able to play this game the longest I've played anything in one sitting.  I expected to have to switch back to teleportation or put it down after 15-20 minutes.  I was pleasantly surprised 2 and a half hours later when I realized what time it was.  I was getting pretty sick because of getting used to flying the ship with a Virtual HOTAS (Hands on Throttle and Stick) because you are actually IN the cockpit and  you grab the throttle and the flight stick and use them.

VR Sickness Frame of Reference: I'm pretty sensitive to VR sickness but I'm getting better by doing it anyway and stopping when i start to feel sick.

184780088.review:
It's a great game, and I'm proud of the devs for turning its rocky beginnings around on a full 180 towards greatness. What I'm disappointed in is the limited time events through expeditions and even the DLC that they released and then took down for Christmas around the time of me writing this. While I understand that it's great for keeping people coming back by having limited edition content, but some of us just don't get the memo in time or don't even have the time to do that stuff in the first place.

The only things I want to see different beyond that is ship customization after claiming ships or making new ones. The same would be nice for the guns, too. I also hear that there's a character customization that only comes after you beat the game, and it doesn't even do anything to improve gameplay -- You're just a special type of alien and that's it... so, why put it there and lock it at the end of the game when it's hardly even a trophy of your travels?

184768015.review:
I started No Man's Sky back in November and it has been a struggle to play anything else.
While it is not the game I expected, I fell in love with it regardless. 
I was expecting a more "hardcore" survival game. With hunger, a player-driven economy/trade system, having to refuel at space stations between destinations, etc. 
What I got instead is a cozy, survival-lite, with breath-taking views.
I have taken more screenshots in NMS in the past two months, than I have all other games from the past 20 years combined.
There are still a lot of features I wish the game had, but none-the-less I consider it a genuine masterpiece.
So much so that Light No Fire is now my most anticipated game of the foreseeable future.

184752229.review:
[h3] Recommended, BUT, not for everyone [/h3]

This is up there with some of my favourite games. I find it a great game to relax and chill with. After the learning curve tapers off, you have a nice variety of things to do. Most centred around exploring (be it o foot, in a vehicle on land, in a spaceship, or aboard your freighter). With that said, if you don't enjoy relaxing and exploring around a huge game, at a slower than average game pace. This may not be for you.

[b] Below, I'll state first, what I believe are games strengths, such as things to do. After that, list what may put some players off from playing or enjoying the game [/b]

[u] Things to do you may enjoy [/u]

* You will not be able to say you finished the game, unless you're only focusing on achievements.
As an exploration game, there is no end to it. Some may feel lost or without direction or motivation with this. This is why it's an important question to ask yourself, do you want to relax exploring? If yes, you are more likely to enjoy it.

* Due to the games design and randomised nature, you'll find many variations of the same thing. Perfect examples are pets  tool/gun and ships (you can also ride pets with a few conditions on that such as size). It can be fun not only finding a rare creature or ship you want to own, but the type, colour, attributes among a number of other factors. If there's something you are particularly interested in, that you've seen a video or picture of. There are websites, reddit threads and more where they explain where they are and how they found them. You use what I will call Stargates here (since most people can imagine how that works). In a nut shell, if you know the address to the location of interest, and find one of these gates near you, and have what you need to start it up and use it (there are guides on that on steam and youtube btw). You can dial the address, go to that system, get what you were interested in and then return.

*This game to this day, continues to recieve new updates. Almost all the things I can remember being promised before this game launched, is now in the game. You want to play with a friend? yes you can. Want to build a base to mine stuff for you while you're offline? yes you can. Want pirates (or be one) and pirate trade hubs? Yes, although it is a bit basic imho. Want to buy some ships and hire pilots to be your wingmen so you're not fighting or defending on your own every time? Yes you can. You can build bases underwater along with a sub, you can unlock a high mobility hover vehicle, and base parts to build a race track if you want. Do you want to make $$$? Again yes you can. I remember hitting the currency limit and ship hanger limits back in 2021 I think. But they've expanded since then. Even the number of pets you can own, has grown. They've added new bioms, ships, creatures, base parts, among other things. They've completely reworked ships and freighters adding more features. Even features other game Dev's have rolled out as DLC such as VR, Hello Games has provided free. Recently they seem to be focusing now on using what they're learning on their new project and adding some of that retrospectively into this game, with new water effects among other things. 

* There is a basic story you can choose to follow or simply ignore and do your own thing. The point of the game or story is to 'reach the centre' of the galaxy. In the long run, you can later then go into a different galaxy with different attributes. You want more lush worlds? Or a dead galaxy to challange yourself? Want more or less hostiles? These are options as you continue to play the game.

* You can own frigetes with their own uses, and send them on missions to collect goodies for you. These missions can ranges from a few hours to nearly a day. But it continues while you're ingame or not. So if you don't have much time, you can send them on missions, buy what you need to make fuel for them and rinse and repeat. Though that can be tricky depending on where you are and what is for sale in your region. Sometimes you may simply need to do some fuel mining yourself. See if you can trade with another player for different goods, or look up guides to automate some of those things.

* But the main thing, is this entire game is about exploring planets, solar systems, and galaxies. Best enjoyed at a slow pace imo. It can be quite relaxing, and then having a slow goal you may be working to. It might be going through the hoops to obtain, grow, and upgrade a living ship. Or maybe making the ultimate semi-automated base, where you come in, grab A+B, put into a reactor, then grab C + D, put them into a reactor, then get the ouputs from both and make a mid or even high value componenet to sell on the market in bulk.  Or maybe it could be farming nanites, or doing the expeditions they regularly have and collecting some rare once off stuff. Maybe it's finding different pets, and going through the breeding system to change the offsprings properties, like size, colour, temperment among other things. Or again, maybe just building a super mega base or artwork if that's what you enjoy.

[u] Ok so now Issues that may be what ruins the experience for you personally  [/u]

* First for many is FOMO. As it is currently setup, if you miss the public expeditions, which run for a set time, that is it, you missed out. They usually run it again at some point, but again, you have limited time to complete it. This is one of my biggest gripes with the game. By all means, have the expeditions, but at least allow people to finish them at their own pace and still collect the goodies for completion be it in a few days, or a year. As for me, rushing the game, takes the fun away from it. But I know others enjoy the rush through it. Other players however are very busy and simply don't have time. Or they like to play a variety of games and don't want to feel pressured to just play one game with what little time they have for maybe a couple of weeks or so (depends on the person and other factors).
I believe the Dev's can strike it halfway like I mentioned so everyone's happy, it's still a community event, but also then nobody would miss out for not finishing in time, so to speak.

* Due to the design of the game, many may feel lost or some what bored without direction. So I'd try consider trying older cheaper games that are similar in some way. like X:3 Terran Conflict (or maybe X:Rebirth,  as you don't get to fly big ships directly), another suggestion might be minecraft, or Elite, maybe Proteus . If you can enjoy that sort of game play, that will hopefully increase your chance of enjoying this.

* As I mentioned above, it is a large game, and there are a varriety of things to do, and work towards. However, to this day, it feels like an ocean that is mostly waist deep. After awhile, it will feel samey for you. Espeacially with ships, the tool/guns, and creatures. With the rare exceptions.
You have base building, and even basic electronics, but doesn't hold a candle to games such as satisfactory, factorio, minecraft and many others with what you can truly achieve. Even with the base parts themselves. Experienced players learnt to glitch the base building to enable placement of parts in more interesting ways. With this game, you'd probably have to try Nexus for mods if you want something interesting added, I haven't bothered with that as there are large updates on a regular basis, I don't want to risk loosing saves or messing up game files. Simply not worth it for me personally.

* Procedually generated content in most games still has the issue of leading to strange, wierd, or samey content. It would really take a good starting platform, then a well optimised AI to sort through permutations to pick out what is actually interesting, or logical to put in the game so it fits with the world building. You want to see Aliens, not a Deer with a fly for a head. It's better than it was, but could stil improve.

184750451.review:
Such an incredible game and I would personally like to thank every person who told me to go against my skepticism and try this out. Beautiful game from start to finish (whenever finishing is supposed to occur lol). This  game receives a lot of criticism so allow me to clarify why.

This game, for all intents and purposes, is a pretty colors game. This is not a shoot em up bang bang game. This is not an E-Commerce simulator. This is not a complex construction simulator. It is not a hardcore survival simulator. Yes, it incorporates qualities of all of the aforementioned genres. But while these are all present in the game, this game is literally designed to be comfortable, imaginative, whimsical, and inspire curiosity and joy. In layman's terms, it is a kid's game on crack. 

Due to its scale and creativity I think this is one of the best games ever made. But if you were going into this expecting a cool manly space simulator thats hard as fuck and has dynamic this that and the third blah blah blah, there are better options for you. For E-Commerce, X4. For more shooty bang bang, Starfield. But if you wanna blow some trees and see trippy shit this is the game for you.

如果你在寻找一款能真正让你沉浸其中的游戏，《无人深空》绝对值得一试。这游戏的世界观简直宏大得让人窒息——它创造了一个几乎无限的宇宙，里面有数不清的星球等待你去探索。每次当你降落到一个新星球时，感觉就像是第一个发现这片土地的人，那新鲜感和未知感真的无与伦比。
而说到自己构建建筑，这又是一大乐趣点！你能在这个浩瀚宇宙中找到一块属于自己的角落，从零开始建立基地。想象一下，在一个遥远星球上，你不仅能在荒野中生存下来，还能亲手搭建起一座庇护所，看着它一点点成长，直到变成一个复杂的基地网，那种成就感无法言喻。而且，你还可以根据个人喜好来装饰和优化你的基地，让它独一无二。《无人深空》不仅仅是一款游戏，更是一场充满惊喜和个人表达的星际冒险。

Even before the release I wanted to play this product, but when the first terrible reviews came in I didn't buy it. Now, many years later, I finally bought the game. My respect to the creators of this game! Getting up after a knockout is already an incredible victory.
I haven't played many games like this. Maybe there are hundreds of games like this, I don't know. But the ability to land on a planet anywhere, the ability to visit seemingly an infinite number of planets with always different biomes and life forms, to take off straight into space from a planet without loading is amazing. The feeling of crazy freedom is wonderful. Except for the moment when I flew to a new star system and immediately got into a space battle, survived and then repaired my ship for the next couple of hours, but that was cool too!
So if you are a fan of a sandbox with a survival vibe and watch channels about space, you should definitely play this. But be lenient with the implementation of SSTO and some conventions, the game is still great. 
And special thanks for giving me the opportunity not to see other players, I don’t like people.

184708630.review:
No Man's Sky is by far the best space exploration game I've ever played, and I doubt I'll find another in the future that tops it. Since I first played on console a few years back, the game has changed significantly. The sheer amount of content and things to do is overwhelming now. You can explore a nearly endless amount of planets across multiple galaxies which look absolutely stunning, build epic bases on those planets, take control of a settlement and guide its people, become an outlaw and smuggle illegal goods for profit, hunt for the best starship or create your own, captain a massive freighter with an entire fleet of frigates to send off on missions, even bake cookies! On top of all that, there are limited-time expeditions with exclusive rewards that offer a new experience, and the ability to collaborate to build bases and take on missions with other players. The multiplayer experience is cool, but personally I find the game to be singleplayer focused, as everyone has their own goals and wants to make progress towards different things.

The universe of No Man's Sky is vast, and you'll have a hard time getting bored with so much to do. If you're into adventure and survival games, or just love space and wish to live among the stars, this game sure delivers! Also make sure to try out camera mode, I've got some insanely sick wallpapers from this game.

184701424.review:
By the time I picked it up, they'd already improved the game a *lot* from its infamous launch, and they're *still* adding to it.

The graphics are amazing. Gameplay switches smoothly between spaceflight, walking and ground vehicles, and between solo and multi-player scenarios. The story is not so much “story” as it is a collection of lore, which you uncover through the main missions and random exploration.

What I like about No Man's Sky is that it combines aspects of Minecraft (which I played a lot of during the late 2010s and into 2020) and Wing Commander: Privateer (which I played a LOT of back in the 1990s). Both open-ended, self-directed sandboxes. Like Minecraft, you seek out resources and build equipment and bases. Like Privateer, you fly through space and do different types of missions depending on what you feel like that day.

The infinite worlds do eventually start blurring together, and a lot of the gameplay is the same thing you've done before, just dressed up differently and with better equipment or more inventory slots. But it's still fun, and I'm still playing it four years on.

184687587.review:
I bought NMS as a peak VR experience game and let me tell you I have not been disappointed. When you are first learning the menus and inventories etc, especially in VR it is overwhelming. Still, after adjusting and becoming familiar with the interface and mechanics the game gets much deeper quickly. I noticed a lot of negative reviews all had a similar theme, they either were dissatisfied with the "depth" of the game in that it felt like a resource harvesting grinder, or that there is no real objective goal and since the game is procedurally generated it becomes boring quickly. Well, I got a little of this vibe early game, maybe my first 10 to 20 hours playing the game, but once you understand the mechanics for discovering new technologies and blueprints the game changes very quickly. 

You can automate almost any task that you may feel is "grindy" and can learn automated mining technologies and setup deep mines that are automated if you despise resource gathering. You can do the same with farming-specific plants and other materials if you dislike that aspect of the game. This opens up the world for you to explore and base build or just do anything else you find more enjoyable. If you are just hopping from planet to planet without actually exploring a planet's ruins, trade terminals/stations, or trying to find the coolest spots (or specific spot/landscapes you desire) to build a base (even underwater), then you are going to get bored. 

This game is really about the journey being the enjoyable part of the game. If you treat it like an MMORPG that you want to have the best rated, coolest, or strongest best stuff you are going to burn yourself out. This game should never feel grindy and when I'm doing something that is no longer fun and starts to feel like a grind I move on to doing something else. I find I have the most fun when I decide to set a random objective for myself. Such as finding earth-like planets that are environmentally gentle/calm and habitable with great views to build a base, or build an underwater base with a submarine dock to search for crashed/sunken starships to collect and harvest their parts that I find cool for a future custom ship that I wish to make at some point in the future. The freighter opens up a world of possibilities as it is essentially a mobile base from which you can control a fleet to do missions. You can add farming rooms, trade terminals, storage etc. This makes the acquisition of money and many materials passive and lets you go and do other things like search for abandoned ruins for ancient archaeological valuables to collect or sell, hunt down pirates, and become a drug smuggler, among countless others. 

I only have about 60 hours on this game and feel like I have barely scratched the surface of the content and depth of this game. My advice, take your time, and don't grind something if you don't enjoy it, there is always something else you can discover, develop, or do that is fun or in some way very enjoyable. Enjoy the journey as this game is all about the journey. Upgrade your technologies so you need fewer resources to survive and explore. Build a base on every planet that you find useful (for any particular resources or purposes you may have) or beautiful planets/sites for potential base sites and name them so you know what is there and can teleport back to it from any space station. Do some of the first main quest missions and from there, allow yourself to get distracted and sidetracked and take your time to understand the mechanics of researching and discover modules and technologies as they change your gameplay experience completely. 

All in all, this game is endless for the people who can figure out how to enjoy the journey and set personal goals that are not always about building the biggest base or getting the "best" ship, freighter, equipment, etc. There are countless things I've yet to do and there's no push to get them done within any timeline until I'm ready to do so. Nonetheless, I can see how it is a game that is not for certain people, but this is not a fault inherent to the quality of the game itself, but rather a gamer's taste in the style and type of games they enjoy. If you can catch this game on sale, it is a steal as you will likely be playing it for years and they continuously update and add new things. If you pay full price, you will find that it is well worth its price tag, and if most players give it a fair shot they'll find it was worth it and get a relative amount of enjoyment compared to the price tag. Most players will enjoy it and get infinitely more out of it than what they paid for it. If you're on the fence, just do it, I don't believe you'll regret it.

В NMS это контрится мультиплеерным хабом на станции-ядре и совместными активностями в составе пати там же.

Еще тут 100500мильонов звезд и планет, но они до последней обновы были крайне однотипными и даже та же фауна дублировалась, сейчас разработчики вдохнули немного свежего воздуха в генерацию и стало интереснее.
В общем и целом, даже если пытаться не брать во внимание, как эта игра менялась и улучшалась стараниями разрабов  с каждым патчем, то как песочница-сурвайвл своих денег точно стоит! Рекомендую!

184686444.review: Gameplay is very open ended and allows the player to choose what kind of adventure they like. I tend to play this game casually, looking for cool critters and beautiful planets, and there is no lack of either. Missions are fun, especially with some pals, and some of the writing in the "main" story line is incredibly poignant and beautiful. I'd absolutely encourage anyone to give the game a shot.

184686113.review:
Als je op een dag zin hebt om een alfa-versie van een spel te testen dat al acht jaar in ontwikkeling is, dan is dit echt een aanrader! Er zitten tientallen systemen in het spel en allemaal werken ze niet goed!

Bouwen is vrijwel onmogelijk. Het 'klik'-systeem werkt voor geen meter. Niet alle onderdelen passen op elkaar. Muur-decoraties verdwijnen in muren in plaats van dat ze er op worden geplaatst, etc.

Planeten zijn mega saai; zodra je er één hebt gezien, heb je ze allemaal wel gezien. Dit geldt ook voor ruimtestations: elk station is exact hetzelfde als de vorige.

De interface is werkelijk een hel om je doorheen te worstelen. Sommige menu's verlaat je met escape, andere met rechter muisknop, en weer andere met tab. Ook beweegt alles als je je cursor beweegt, is elk menu geanimeert, en het werkt gewoon allemaal mega frustrerend.

Een aantal missies werken niet goed als je met meerdere mensen speelt. Vooral de 'dood X vijanden'-missies, waarbij de teller gewoon niet oploopt.

Dit spel is een oefenig in frustratie. De enige reden dat ik er nog zoveel tijd in heb gestopt is omdat ik het met iemand speel die het leuk vindt en ik het oké genoeg vind om samen te spelen, maar man man man wat een bagger troep is dit zeg.

I would have said yes prior to this moronic drone patched in that never goes away despite completing the quest chain. Seriously you have to start a settlement and complete a quest chain just to turn the thing off, and then it still bugs and doesn't work. Make the quest so you opt-in, not out. And really, 1 settlement in all of space? Just have multiple or do away with the mechanic. 1 settlement is an annoying task to complete just to get rid of a drone i don't want in the first place. It either runs away from you when you want to talk or when you want to loot something it's in your face and you can't avoid interacting in the middle of combat. Would be fine if I could dismiss during combat but alas it never goes away.
The community expedition was fun at first but the community aspect is terrible. Rolling up to a planet i've never seen should be fun, but when there's already 50 bases on my radar and i just want to pulse to the quest destination but can't because it tags a community base...just frustrating. I have all available options turned off for community and yet it is pervasive and annoying. Give the ability to limit what you see to friends or just single player. The community expedition goals were useless as well. I completed the expedition 3 times and still never got the 4th optional one complete. Again the community portion of the community expedition being the worst part. This game would be amazing single player with zero community crap to break immersion, or when you want to see everyone make it optional.

184666834.review:
Preordered back then with minimal expectations, but was disappointed anyways. Now over the years I've picked it up multiple times and was always surprised how much the game has changed. There are some weird things and bugs popping up from time to time but to be fair, the game is huge and I can't even imagine how convoluted the code-base might be after all these years of upgrades. For me as a dev myself it's almost a miracle that it's not constantly breaking down.

That being said - yes the hype at release and basically selling a tech-demo with not nearly covering a fraction of what has been promised was a pretty bad move, but you've learned from it and worked very hard to prove that the bought game can live up to your dream.

Thanks to the team for keeping it up and delivering a lot of major updates over the years for free (which would be a dlc each with other games). 

Recommended for everyone who really likes exploration in a scifi setting.

184648593.review:
メインストーリークリアまでおよそ５０時間程度。建築やアンロックなどで＋１００時間は掛かるボリュームで価格以上に遊べます。メインストーリーの出来は傑作。神秘的で思想的。中々考えさせられる感じで面白いです。

オープンワールドのマップは非常識なほど広く、銀河ー惑星系ー惑星ー準惑星ー衛星の流れもそのまま再現され、惑星はもちろん小さい衛生にまで自由に離着陸できるのはスゴイ！

ただ、、恐ろしく広大なのは良いが、街となる宇宙ステーションのパターンが２種類とオンライン用のロビーが１つだけとかなり物足りない。また、無数にある惑星に関しても植物・生態系・環境のパターンが各々数十種類の組み合わせで、２０時間程度プレイすると何処に行っても見たことがある世界になるのが非常に残念な所。

一応、オープンワールドのオンラインゲームですが、基本はオンライン用のロビー以外で人と合う事はありません。惑星を最初に見つけると自分の名前を刻める仕様になっていて、一番人が多いゲーム開始時の銀河では名前が付いた惑星を見かけるが最初の銀河から離れると常に自分が第一発見者の状態になり、人の気配が全くない世界観で進んでいく。

ゲーム発売当初の２０１６年は酷評の嵐で買う気にならなかったが２０２４年の現在まで地道にアップデートを続けて「非常に好評」の評価にまで上がった。現在も頻繁にアップデートがあり進化し続けているゲームと言える。今後は自動生成のＡＩ化が進んで惑星内のグラフィックや複雑なストーリーとクエストが無数に出来れば一生遊べるゲームになる可能性を秘めている。

184589381.review:
[h1] 如果宇宙都是虚拟的，那么生命还有什么意义
回答，生命本身就是意义 [/h1]

无人深空所给我们的，与其他游戏所终于不同的是，它不是给玩家一个固定的世界去进行探索，取而代之的是一个近乎无限无序的宇宙，无论是有机体还是无机体，无论是实体还是能量体，都那么鲜活的呈现在你面前，无论是即将爆炸的恒星，无论是新生的星系，都有全新的生命孕育其中，玩家，抑或推至每一个生物，所要做的只有生存而已，而仅仅是生存有时也遥不可及

由此，才要探索，要发展，也由此，才有了工具，有了科学，更由此，才得以探索更大的世界，终由此，才得以生存

每一个生物，每一个生命，无一不重复着这条规律，也无一不印证了这条规律，无论生命的形态如何变化，倘若不终于生存下去，则一切都虚无缥缈，则生命的意义，从来也不在于外界，不在于环境，而正在于其本身，宇宙又如何，在生命面前也不过如微尘般渺小，现实的宇宙与虚拟的宇宙，对生命来说只不过是容器之分，而绝非根本之区别

如果一个生物，已然学会使用工具，已然有了政权与经济，已然有了种族观念，已然有了属于自己的情绪与思考，那么是否可以被称为人呢，抑或者，当人的概念来到了宇宙，则是否应该被外延呢

无“人”深空，似乎正是这样，但又似乎是要被否定的，这些都是未知，却又已然有了答案

浩瀚的深空宇宙，究竟有没有生命，如果无法被探知，那么其之存在与否又有意义吗
我想答案是很明显的

如果看看我们现在的这个世界------很可惜，又很幸运的是------不是虚拟的，对我来说，我是相信一定有地球之外的生命的，虽然一切的生命终于只能落到实体去由物质组成，但智慧生物的出现是生物进化的偶然也是必然，地球得天独厚的位置也绝非无法复现，只是时间问题而已

到时候，我们是否可以与之和谐共处，还是要大动干戈，就不得而知了
------------------------------------------------------
感想编完啦，接下来就该是我最擅长写的对游戏的感受了

首先，游戏真的是弄了个非常大的世界去探索，虽然每个星球和系统都是系统生成的，但很少会有重复的星球和生物，游戏里面还有很多奇奇怪怪的生物，游戏也都给写了生物详情，虽然读上去感觉又乱又奇怪但终归是有

游戏本身的玩法是生存探索，主线任务可做可不做，单纯的探索也足够满足了，每个星球独特的矿物和天气系统也让玩家的游玩体验可难可易

成就系统就比较难受了，绝大多数成就都是和游戏内的里程碑挂钩的，其中需要玩家找动物的和在极端条件下生存的有点过于难了，其余的都很好做

每当玩家进入到星系中心的时候就可以选择是否前往新的星系，这时你会重生到一个全新的星系和星球上且身上的绝大多数装备都会损坏，但这个重生不会给你重生到一个绝对安全的地方，我就被重生到了一个又极端低温又有风暴的地方，复活在一个平原上又没有工具，连挖洞都挖不了，基本上可以说是死档了，我只能找风灵月影不然30多个小时的永久死亡存档就彻底废了

总的来说还是很推荐的游玩的，现在的丰富程度已经足以称得上优秀了，只可惜要是刚发售的时候就有这样的质量就好了

184573480.review:
When I first heard about No Man’s Sky, I was drawn in by its promise of endless exploration in a vast, procedurally generated universe. I used to play on ps4 and while I didn't play much at launch the game didn’t quite live up to the hype. But over the years, No Man’s Sky has transformed into something truly incredible. As a player that has come back to the game after many years, I can confidently say that this game is a masterpiece that most definitely took time and effort—not just for what it is today but for the journey it’s taken to get there. Returning to the game from its launch it doesnt even feel like the same game.

The amount of care Hello Games has put into improving this game is mind-blowing. Every update feels like unwrapping a gift. Features like base-building, frigate management, underwater exploration, and full-blown multiplayer have added so much depth. The new Expeditions mode, with its community-driven challenges, keeps things fresh even after hundreds of hours of gameplay. And let’s not forget the addition of VR—which may be clunky is still a fun feature to play around with if you have the capabilities.

Graphically, No Man’s Sky is a feast for the eyes. I’ve played it on a ps4 and later upgraded to a decent pc system, and both experiences were smooth and stunning. While the ps4 was still clunky, it was most definitely playable. The game’s settings are incredibly customizable on pc, which I really appreciate. You can tweak the graphics to prioritize performance or max them out for breathtaking visuals. Whether you're gazing at a surreal alien sunrise or flying through asteroid fields in the void of space, the game’s beauty never fails to amaze. For me this helped because my pc is subpar.

What stands out most, though, is the way Hello Games treats its community. Every update is free, and the developers genuinely listen to feedback. They didn’t just abandon the game after its rocky start—they embraced the criticism, rebuilt trust, and turned No Man’s Sky into something that exceeds expectations.

In conclusion I believe this game is playable for everyone. There's creative and hardcore, alot of crafting, fighting, exploring, missions, collectables such as starships, frigates, pets, amazing base building... The list goes on and on. I believe that you should only get this game if you have the time because with all the features it is extremely addicting.

Comprei este banger em 2022, mas apenas tive vontade de jogar no final de 2024. Não deu outra, fiquei extremamente viciado e torrei horas nesta bagatela (sequer cheguei na metade da quest principal, a maior parte do tempo foi gasto autistando espaço à fora). Facilmente uma das experiências mais agradáveis que tive com videojogos. Confesso que a falta de inimigos para estourar me incomoda, não que o combate seja inexistente, mas definitivamente o foco aqui não é ação e trocação de tiro. Entretanto, a exploração, o grind para conseguir bons equipamentos, a construção de bases, o fato de você poder pegar uma nave dreadnought e as constantes atualizações gratuitas pesam positivamente na balança. 

No geral, se você é um fã de FPS, tiroteio, porradaria franca, genocídio, matança, de tratar as convenções de Genebra como uma checklist, talvez este jogo te faça ter sono. Mas se o que lhe agrada é a exploração, aventura, construção de bases, gerenciamento de vilarejos e colônias, a liberdade de ser desde um pirata espacial até um comerciante que pratica usura na cara dura, provavelmente irá adorar esta pérola.

184549877.review:
Ich gehöre zu denjenigen, die das Spiel vorbestellt und nach dem verbockten Start eine Rückerstattung verlangt haben. Vor gut einem Jahr habe ich es dann wieder gekauft, und der Kaufpreis hat sich mehr als gelohnt. Über 300 Stunden lang habe ich viel Spaß gehabt mit dem Spiel, alle Missionen habe ich abgeschlossen und zwar mit Freude. Nun spiele ich gern die Expeditionen, die eine geschickte Methode sind, so würde ich es ausdrücken, um noch einmal "fast frisch anzufangen" -- man beginnt quasi mit nix, aber hat letztlich doch Zugriff auf wesentliche Teile des Spielstands (also Multitool und Raumschiff).

Die Story ist ungewöhnlich. Und Sie wird sehr ungewöhlich erzählt, nämlich in teils wirren Stücken, die man peu à peu zusammenpuzzzelt. Im Grunde ist die Story Assassin's Creed nicht unähnlich, mehr kann ich nicht sagen, ohne zu spoilern — wird aber hier mit viel mehr Hintersinn verpackt. Mir gefällt, dass das Spiel weniger auf Brutalität und weniger auf Horror setzt als die meisten anderen auf dem Markt. Es ist farbenfroh und (im Rahmen des nihilistischen Settings) auch hoffnungsfroh. Das mag ich. Die Schwierigkeit steigt an, aber es gibt keine Boss-Kämpfe. Ich mag keine Boss-Kämpfe, denn für die muss ich stundenlang die Choreographie studieren — das ist nicht mein Verständnis von Spielspaß. Hier ist die Reise das Ziel, ganz klar. Und das ist sehr nach meinem Geschmack.

184539527.review: Pra mim, No Mans Sky é a realização de um sonho. Nascemos numa época onde a exploração espacial não é alcançável ou realizável para nós meros sonhadores. Nos resta sonhar através de obras fictícias como livros, filmes e masterpieces como essa aqui. Particularmente, o jogo me transporta de uma forma tão sublime que consigo me desapegar completamente da realidade. A sensação de liberdade, de descoberta, de que não precisa ter pressa para ir atrás do infinito, são sensações únicas que esse jogo passa. 184524531.review:
Jeu d'exploration spatiale et galactique (256 galaxies composées de milliards de systèmes constitués de jusqu'à 6 corps célestes au total de planètes et/ou lunes explorables avec chacune leur propre biome, faune, flore,minéraux, points d'eau et relief, le tout généré de façon procédurale), vaste bac à sable (exploration, construction, farming (ressources, vaisseaux, armes, cargo, compagnons, bases planétaires, etc...) absolument fantastique avec mises à jour gratuites régulières. Solo ou multijoueurs, cross plateforme et cross save. Quêtes journalières / hebdomadaires les weekend/ expéditions événementielles, que du bonheur. 
Quêtes principales qui font tutoriel. S'il y a effectivement des batailles et des bug parfois, il ne me semble pas que ce soit 1 jeu de combat et qu'il mérite vraiment que l'on se fasse plaisir dessus. Surtout qu'il y a des communautés (Babel, francophone,..etc.) actives et prêtes à aider.
Cela fait plus de 4.185h depuis 8/2022 que j'y joue, je suis toujours agréablement surpris des diverses découvertes que j'y trouve et je sais que j'y jouerai encore jusqu'à la fin. Bon marathon à tous, il en vaut la peine ;-)

184504125.review:
I've really tried to enjoy No Man's Sky (given how much the developers care about and release updates for the game) and honestly it does some things really well - spaceflight, combat, planet design, and interacting with space stations were all things I found cool. Initially.

After playing this game for probably 20 hours I began to lose interest, for a couple different reasons. The main problem is that the game is quite repetitive and is completely self-directed. You have several options for things to do (build, explore, trade, and fight) with no ultimate goal or motivation. Every time I opened up No Man's Sky after the 20-hour mark I closed the game shortly after since I just didn't feel like doing anything in the game. For example, I spent some time gathering some materials to get to a new star system since it seemed interesting, only to find just another boilerplate system inhabited by a familiar species with planets that looked cool initially but were similar to ones I had found before. I was never drawn to the optional side quests you find either or even the main storyline.

I can see why some people appreciate it as it truly is a sandbox game and you can do whatever interests you. But that's only sustainable if there are interesting things to do, of which in my opinion runs out fairly quickly after you've been to a couple star systems.

184500896.review:
No Man's Sky is quite a weird game. If you watch videos about it, you can either see people just endlessly walking around or fly ships all day. And you're right, that's pretty much it. But unlike some more recent space games, such as Starfailed, they managed to keep the most basic gameplay fun.

A couple years ago, I gave the game a shot during a twitch campaign. Back then the game couldn't hold me and I dropped it the same day I picked it up. BUT after giving it another shot (again during a twitch campaign), I suddenly  got a hang on it and to my surprise, it got me hooked.

I can't say what exactly it is that makes me like the game. I mean sure, the visual style is nice, the Atlas design is awesome but there is also so much jank like no voice acting, it's all plain text, some UX aspects being very undercooked etc. Maybe it's exactly this. The game isn't doing anything outstanding. But it's coherent, it works and it does its job fine.

Anyways, with that being said, let me manage your expectations: the game is a chill game to hang around and walk through worlds. There is no engaging story, the content itself is average, there is no progression whatsoever. You're just unlocking new features one after another but if you are looking for something to minmax to death, you're not going to get it here.

So if you want to play a game that just exists and isn't actively trying to catch your attention at any given minute, this game is for you. You can leave at any time and come back and you won't miss out on anything. Expeditions, which are basically seasons, apparently do repeat at some point and even without them you're still getting a full and nice epxerience.

184465834.review: Devs did a wonderful job re-creating this game after the massive public outcry years ago; As a space game player I would be amiss to not ask other space game players to give No Mans Sky a shot. Base building, Expedition mode, and community events keep veteran players coming back for more and new players have total freedom over how they want to play, unfettered by veteran players in their space. Try to rescue a space-time prisoner and uncover secrets of the universe along the way, or seek a more transhumanist approach and merge with machine. Game is best with 1-2 other players that also play, multiplayer is functional but still has hiccups and can lose connection, particularly during PvE combat. I most often find myself building bases, sending out frigates on missions, running expeditions in expedition mode, and dancing at other peoples bases. :)

184448528.review:
I've only played NMS in VR mode, with an Oculus Rift S, so I'm reviewing from a VR game perspective.

I have some minor gripes about the VR controls, as some of the basebuilding aspects (which are the most fun parts of the game) and anything involving text entry tend to be quite flaky. Some mechanics also feel like they're deliberately designed to keep you grinding longer instead of really adding interesting new content, especially the later updates like colony building.

That said, NMS is the only game that scratches the itch for me to build a nice home in VR, and the controls are really well designed for VR, they're not just thrown in as an afterthought like a lot of games with VR modes.

It's definitely the best VR game I've ever played, by a wide margin, and probably accounts for half of my total VR time.

184445907.review:
Симулятор бесконечности . Процедурная генерация это будущее игр . Благодаря ей мы даже не сможем посетить все 18 секстиллионов 446 квинтиллионов 744 квадриллиона 073 триллиона 709 миллионов 551 тысяча 616 планет в игре - не хватит жизни каждого человека на Земле, чтобы успеть посетить их . 
Поэтому 99 % посещенных вами систем для вас еще никем не открыто (очень редко попадаются при путешествиях чужие системы) , и вы первопроходец - вы можете назвать ее и планеты как угодно (лично я ставил ссылку на мой вк))) . главное зарядить все двигатели и вперед . 
сюжет в игре есть , но он и нафиг не нужен , просто можно путешествовать и торговать , строить базы на планетах , и возможно грабить огромные грузовые корабли (как я понял покупать на черном рынке информацию о кораблях , за баснословные деньги, и потом со своей эскадрильей (можно нанимать нпс) окупать затраты. 
Игру однозначно рекомендую , жаль что познакомился с ней в 2024

184432818.review: 这鬼游戏狗屎一样的引导，狗屎一样的任务结算，狗屎一样的游戏深度，狗屎一样的BUG数量，狗屎一样的游戏内容优化，以及及其逆天的多人游戏体验，堪称灾难。飞船没有星球自动坐标巡航，没有方向指针，没有目标地点位置附近的建筑根本无法定位到具体的坐标。多人游戏基地权限模糊不清，同群组+steam好友+全权限，队友一进异象或离开本星系，你连在基地放个精炼机都不行的狗屎设定；搞出来的太阳能S飞船因为和朋友一起做主线任务导致直接被朋友的飞船模型覆盖，重新读档飞船直接不是太阳能飞船了，直接变成一个装有太阳能帆的战舰飞船，这样的逆天bug不胜枚举。这鬼游戏要庆幸自己没有修复可以刷东西的bug，不然根本不会有多少人能玩玩下去，完全不推荐任何想要深入体验这个游戏的玩家入坑，不仅大部分内容纯自己刷根本不可能刷的出来，只能通过bug来获取。游戏深度及其低下，建造内容判定离谱，垂直玻璃通道居然没有开口，建造条件是链接两个建筑，然后你造了之后这个沟槽的垂直玻璃通道的双边通道口都是无法进入的，根本没有建造意义，水体内容基本等于没有。所有内容广而不精，当你发现一个系统有意思的时候这个系统的深度就直接到此为止了，根本没有其他任何内容，完全没有任何的细节可言还有巨量的bug，这些内容严重影响你的游戏进程，单纯是友谊让我能坚持玩这么久还能玩下去，而不是这个沟槽的逆天游戏（流汗黄豆）

184424576.review:
Having played over a 1,000 hours, I believe it is fair to state "I like this game"! In my first game (300 hours play) I accepted a Freighter without appreciating all that it entails, sending Frigates on missions to achieve resources isn't for me; so the second game (and my current game) I continue to avoid accepting a Freighter and remain in my own Starship or planet based. I have several starships, a Living Ship is my favourite, though I also enjoy the variety of Sentinel ships, which vary in class, so I searched and found the best one that can achieve close to 1800 hyperdrive and makes space travel quicker when system hopping. I collect resources mostly by walking alongside my Minotaur "Bob", occasionally using my Nautilus or the Roamer. I have over 1,500,000,000 units, nearly 400,000 nanites and 12,000 quick silver (having spent loads of all 3 currencies to upgrade everything). In my opinion the best weapons are the ones the Autophage Monolith provides, second best are the ones available from the Sentinel Pillars.

I've just begun the Expeditions available over this Christmas and these are challenging and rewarding. Though would have loved to have the Bibi Egg from the Omega expedition, was awarded all the others, just not that one.

Here is a little feedback for @HelloGames - it would be great to be able to use the Minotaur with the Roamer (or another land-based craft) using at the same time. Minotaur Bob is a companion as well as a useful backup against sentinels. I miss him on bad weather planets, as often the weather-protection of the Roamer is more efficient /faster than trying to travel inside Bob, but he's a much better companion and protector. Thank you.

*"No Man's Sky" is an absolute gem of a game. It’s got this massive, ever-expanding universe that feels like it's just waiting for you to explore it. The freedom to gather resources, craft, and upgrade is awesome, and I really enjoy figuring out the best ways to get materials like Pugneum or Dioxite. The game doesn't hold your hand, which makes every discovery feel earned, and it’s always satisfying to unlock something new, whether it’s a land vehicle or a cool upgrade.

What really sets it apart for me is how varied it feels. One moment you're mining resources on a frozen planet, and the next you're fending off Sentinels in some high-stakes action. The visuals are stunning, and it’s easy to lose yourself in the beauty of the galaxies.

It’s not just a game—it’s an experience. You can build, explore, fight, and trade, and it never feels repetitive. Plus, there’s always something new being added. I can’t recommend it enough if you love games that give you creative freedom and adventure. Definitely worth your time!"

184365023.review:
One of the greatest comebacks in game development.

No Man's Sky has come a long way since its rocky launch, and as someone who's been along for the ride, it's been incredible to see the game evolve. What originally felt like an empty, grindy experience has transformed into a rich, expansive universe full of surprises. The core of the game—exploring endless, procedurally generated planets—is still what I love most. There’s something magical about landing on a new world, scanning alien creatures, and discovering uncharted places. The crafting and building systems have also gotten much deeper, letting me create my own base, upgrade my equipment, and really feel like I'm part of the universe.

That said, it’s not without its repetitive aspects. Sometimes the loop of mining resources, upgrading gear, and hopping between planets can start to feel a bit monotonous, and the pacing can be slow, especially if you're not focused on the right goals. But the updates have made a huge difference, especially the multiplayer component. Being able to team up with friends and explore together really changes the experience and adds a new layer of fun. The game’s beauty is hard to ignore—each planet is unique, and the sheer variety of creatures and landscapes keeps things exciting. If you’re looking for a relaxing, open-ended space exploration experience, No Man’s Sky has definitely earned its place as one of my favorite games, though it's a game that rewards patience and a willingness to embrace its quiet, contemplative moments.

Fast forward to September 2020 after the Origins update, I decided to give the game another go around. I have enjoyed playing the game since and followed as closely as I could with every new update Hello Games put out. I love playing this game now for what it is today and can easily sink in a few hours without time feeling like a drag. Thank you everyone who has had a hand in creating this game.
