184349869.review:
REAL TALK REVIEWS
-------------

VISUAL: 4/5

No Man's Sky visuals provide a mixture of art and fantasy with science and realism. While that might be confusing to understand, once you boot up the game from any mode and load into your planet, you'll know what I mean. 

The wildlife and its inhabitants are cute and plentiful. However, after awhile you'll notice that the humanoids eventually start to look similar, and the wildlife in each planet - while different - also start to displaying similar body shapes. 

Water looks good, especially during storms. Ships are futuristic, with a touch of realism. The cockpit view is really fun to be in when flying the ship. My wish is that you could see your character's arms and legs in POV to provide extra immersion. 

The UI is clean and easy to understand. The menu for the game is pretty straight forward using a hover menu system. Screen indicators noting when you get hurt or low on levels.

The visual gem of this game is when you finally get on your ship - fly out to space - and then explore the universe. The visuals you get to see are dream like. Colors are bright and vivid. Some galaxies with multiple stars, planets with rings and moons. Some filled with shipwrecks. Heck, you might even see a shipwreck in space! Did I mention there's black holes too? Ahh!

AUDIO: 3/5

The music in the game has a nice sci-fi fantasy feel. It's not an epic orchestra award-like soundtrack, but it fits the game. The sound effects for lasers during battles or mining; sounds of cooking and processing materials are spot on. Ship sounds are good. Explosions sounds good, and storms really do sound like you're in a crazy storm.

The dialogue could be much better though - but it is what it is. And eventually, some sound effects start to get a little annoying (like the robotic narrator that tells you when the storm approaches or if your shields are low). Acquiring items sounds start to take their toll after awhile. Sometimes I do wish the game included more sci-fi sounds. I miss me some Star Wars/ Star Trek effects.

CONTROLS: 3.5/5

The controls pretty easy to learn. Switching between build mode and world mode is quick and easy. Engaging your tool to mine or use it as a weapon isn't hard at all. Flying your ship doesn't require much practice, same with the other vehicles you get later on.

The Minotaur sometimes is annoying to drive. It just feels like it fights your control at times and doesn't respond as well as you'd like. I honestly prefer to have it as an AI bot companion. 

Mining and combat have very similar controls and are pretty straight forward to use. The only gripe is that the multi tool has so many.. "tools" that sometimes it gets annoying to switch between modes to finally find the one you need.

Base building isn't bad on the controller. However, I do recommend using a keyboard + mouse - like any base builder. It's just easier. Plus, sometimes switching first to third (and vice versa) helps with some camera angles.

A fun wish - but not required - is to be able to fly my Freighter manually and have my fleet follow. Just to feel like a boss. But maybe in a future update...?

MECHANICS: 4/5

This game can be experienced both solo or with a group of players. Admittedly, I've only played with a few people for a short period of time during my play-through on consoles, and seeing others on the Anomaly.

Personally, I prefer to play this game in single player. Being able to start it from the beginning alone is how the game should be played at the start. The game does a good job of slowly introducing you to the game mechanics.

Right away you start to get the hang of mining resources and learning how to craft common items needed for everyday things in the game. Soon, the game has you building your first base. Then the game has you flying out into space, and so on. Following the quest line is easy. Figuring out what to do later on - well, that's a different story.

This game provides so many things to do (these will be spoilers):
- You can fly around and explore space - maintaining and upgrading your ship as you go.
- You can hunt for resources and build unique bases throughout the galaxies. Since the last update you can also build bases underwater!
- You can find and manage a settlement as mayor. This includes building new buildings, settling dispute between inhabitants, trading resources, accepting refugees, defending your settlement against attacks!
- You can scour the galaxy and hunt for pirates with a squadron, board wrecked freighters for riches
- You can swim underwater areas and explore new creatures
- You can captain a freighter and build a fleet - sending them to missions - while base building ON your freighter.
- You can build and grow resources, using them for upgrades, base building, or for cooking.
- You can visit other players bases and experience their creativity
- You can continue with the main quest line and make it to the center of the universe

This game continuously gets support from the developers after a very rough launch. Since then, they've given free updates and the game has completely transformed from a train-wreck - to an absolute gem and counting!

PLOT: 3/5

You wake up on a random planet, not knowing how you got there and who you are. The first thing you know is that you're in a space suit and you have a multi tool. Your suit system is telling you what your next steps are in order to survive.

Eventually, you get the means to fly into space. You intercept a distress signal. Who is this person? What's going on here? 

That's really the start of the plot of the game without spoiling too much. I did enjoy the story, especially the mystery it gives. It was surprisingly shorter than I thought it would be. It feels not complete. While I do appreciate the open-ended(ness?) of it - I wish there was a more flushed out story-line. But doing that would require an extensive overhaul to many things. More detailed NPCs to help push the narrative (rather than just a select few on the Anomaly), more scripted moments, more 161616

FUN FACTOR: 4.5/5

No Man's Sky is the standard for what games can be like if the Developers are not greedy and continue to support, continue to develop games for gamer's, not for profit.

Their various modes of play really give room for players to come back and try new things. The replay value of this game is very very high.

If you enjoy base building, you can easily lose yourself in this game for a few hours. Once you start traversing into space and being able to build more things - the hours just continue to add up.

With the added seasonal expeditions and its rewards being able to be transported to your main save - this game just keeps getting better and better. 

Feel like winding down and shoot down some pirates? Sure! Want to farm some illegal grass and sell for profit? Heck yeah! No Man's sky provides such a wide variety of things, it's hard to put down.

--------

VERDICT: 4/5

A space exploration, base building game with combat, farming, settlement building features. With great visuals, and easy to learn mechanics - No Man's Sky is a game that I can recommend to all ages.

While the game does come with many things to do - it is not a master of any of them (at least not at this time). Underwater portions of the game were just upgraded, so there is a chance that everything in NMS can continue to get improvements.

With all of these features coming out of the box, and the replay value of the game - NMS is a gem that should be in every gamer's library.

--------
RTR OVERVIEW
--------
4/5 - VISUALS
3/5 - AUDIO
3.5/5 - CONTROLS
4/5 - MECHANICS
3/5 - PLOT
4.5/5 - FUN FACTOR
---------
4/5 - VERDICT
--------
BUY: YES (Full price - yes, I said it.)
ADD-ONS: None - All free updates (so far).
RTR GAMER'S CHOICE
--------

184315926.review:
1. 好玩
游玩这个游戏的前120个小时，我像是被磁铁吸在这游戏上一样：刚接触它的那几周时间中，我起床就是为了上号开飞船，躺下是因为太困不得不睡
玩法丰富——非常丰富，你可以体会到多个游戏系统，入坑前我以为这是个有更多多边形的Minecraft，现在我想说“没那么简单”
有吸引力，游戏系统和剧情两个方面一直在牢牢地引诱着我直到通关游戏，通关之后，沉浸地在新世界的草坪上看着天空，我还在震撼于自己之前的经历
相信我，如果你和我一样对开放世界探索建造游戏感兴趣，你也会被它像磁铁一样吸住的，钱没白花
2. 本地化支持
有原生完整简体中文汉语支持
3. 有诚意的制作组
至今仍在坚持更新的制作组，所以这游戏中只要出现BUG很快就会Fix掉
不断地推出新远征以供游玩
虽然游戏发行之初缺少内容，但后来的持续更新表明，他们是很有诚意的创作者，值得我用资金对他们的精神和行为进行鼓励，如果打开一个2016年的视频看看当时的游戏，再打开现在的游戏，你也会发出这样的疑问：“现在的内容怎么这么丰富，它们真的是同一个游戏吗？”

美中不足：
对有飞行游戏经验的玩家来说可能需要一个手柄才能有更好的飞行体验，不过问题不大，在地面期间即便没有手柄也对游玩体验无影响
我建议制作组在键鼠与手柄操作方面优化适配一下：
1. 即便设定了“简单”，键鼠操作下还是有太多地方需要长按，我想鼠标指针已经很精准地表明意图了；
2. 有一些地方完全是在用键鼠映射手柄，我记得有A/D承载的操作同时有切换页面与增减数量，以至于有合成东西时会下意识按错之类的问题。既然键盘相比手柄有很多键，也许应该让同一组按键的语义尽可能在所有界面下一致；
3. 在诸如主菜单和暂停菜单页面之类的地方，又存在“用手柄摇杆模拟鼠标”的问题，个人觉得菜单中不太应该推拉摇杆去控制光标，假如提供个吸附+隐藏光标的方案供选择也许不错；
关于键鼠的飞行控制我个人认为目前来看用起来很难受，我这里有两个改进方案：
1. WS控制pitch，AD控制yaw，QE控制roll，Shift和Space控制accelerate，ctrl控制脉冲，鼠标仅控制自由视角不参与驾驶；
2. 将操作选项根据手柄和键鼠分别作存储设定，例如驾驶时视角反转的选项：因为手柄需要反转视角是为了用摇杆模拟飞行器操纵杆进行pitch和row；但鼠标并不是个摇杆设备而是一个定位设备故不需要反转视角。

184280611.review:
What a journey No Man's Sky has been. 

The game starts off real strong; you awaken on a planet, alone. What got you here? Where are you supposed to go? What happened? You ease into every mechanic the game has on offer. You'll learn how to fix equipment, how to build new equipment, how to repair and upgrade spaceships.. Then you'll build bases, you get to build and use vehicles, you'll even have your own freighter. And with the freighter, the option to build your very own navy. You'll explore planets, find treasure. You follow the main mission, sure. But get sidetracked a lot along the way. You'll sink days, heck no, weeks of time into this game. And you'll enjoy every single second of it.

But eventually you'll reach the centre of the universe. There, you'll have to make a choice based on everything you learned getting there. And after that choice, you'll find out what No Man's Sky really means to you. If it's still worthy enough to sink in months of your time.

For me, after 75 hours of playtime, the game ended there.

For others, well, for them it's like they only completed the tutorial. They're hooked for life.

What will No Man's Sky be for you?

184272687.review:
I remember the biggest controversy about this game being about some multiplayer issues, but I've never cared much for multiplayer games so this game just kinda sat there in the back of my mind with no opinion on it. But then it went on sale, i had some spare money, you know how it goes. 
My god its so boring. I was expecting some type of engaging plot, some cool side quests or npcs, anything really. But it's just rise and grind until you make it to the center of the universe, something that takes 20 minutes of moving through the galaxy map to even get to and god only knows how much longer with actual gameplay. And the actual gameplay is just mine->build->move->repeat. With a clunky, messy, unintuitive way of showing you how to play the game, and with needless and constant repetition to make any progress, and with each step forward adding some new nonsense to have to juggle with everything else. I'm all for a sandbox game, but when your game is galaxy wide, maybe give it more than an inch of depth? Nowhere in the game does it feel like i've made any real progress with anything and just getting through the basics of how things work is enough to go over the refund time limit on steam. Younger me, the one who would play Spore for hours unending just messing with planets and expanding an empire until I reach the galactic center, would honestly probably be bored with this game to. I don't think the game is bad, but the people the game is meant for has to be a very, very specific niche and unless you are apart of that niche then this game is just not it at all.

184268608.review:
Não jogue se vc não quer ficar viciado! Tá avisado! rs
Comprei NMS no dia 31-10-2024, e hoje, dois meses depois, já acumulo mais de 360 horas de jogo!
NMS oferece inúmeras opções de jogo, para diferentes perfis de jogadores.
Se você curte explorar novos territórios, ele te oferece 18 quintilhões de planetas diferentes, com diferentes faunas, floras, planetas hostis, que podem variar de +130 gaus celsius até -120, num piscar de olhos. Ou planetas com tempestades gravitacionais, repletos de flora com leds, que às vezes vc simplesmente para tudo para ficar somente admirando a beleza do planeta. Planetas empoeirados, com gases toxicos, radioativos...mermão, o q não falta é opção. Basta procurar!

Se vc curte ter veículos diferentes, o jogo tem vários! É nave de tudo que é tipo e design! É Nave Cargueira! Carro, moto, mech, submarino, ...

Se vc prefere cavalgar em criaturas, vc também pode! Pode ser criatura terrestre ou voadora. (No mar, eu nunca tentei, mas se duvidar, tem tb)

Pra quem gosta de fazer aventuras marinhas, você consegue fazer bases submersas.

As opções de peças para as bases, são inúmeras!

É um jogo para quem curte craftar coisas!

Penso que o ponto mais fraco do jogo, é a parte de combate. 

Mas aqui, você pode ser prefeito de uma cidade.
Vc pode montar sua base numa nave cargueira!
Vc pode montar base em tudo q é planeta por onde passar!
Pode fazer expedições e conquistar recompensas super diferenciadas.
Pode fazer amigos e fazer missoes com eles. A comunidade é maravilhosamente maneira!
Vc pode jogar horas sozinho, mas pode também jogar com outras pessoas.
Pode montar uma frota de naves para explorar o universo.
Pode montar um esquadrão que irá te ajudar nos combates aéreos e espaciais.
Pode até mesmo montar a nave que quer entregar para os seus pilotos contratados (mas isso tem q saber fazer hehehe, pois não é convencional do jogo)

Vc vai ter um exotraje, uma multiferramenta, várias naves, uma nave cargueira, e sei lá mais o que para evoluir!

Após 360 horas, NMS ainda me surpreende! Já é o terceiro jogo que mais joguei na steam, atrás apenas de Miscreated (750h) e Dayz (850h). É um jogo que vc vai jogar, parar, depois voltar a jogar novamente.

Além de tudo, tem uma história legal. Várias, até. Recomendo muito!

Vou parar por aqui, pq acho que já deu para entender que eu curti o jogo. rs

184254340.review:
No mans sky is not a good game. I feel like this should be called TELETUBBIES. The fov by default is like 10 and your body takes up 40% of the screen. Why is the camera so close to the player?? The map design seems like it is missing a nickelodeon logo at the top of the screen. The maps are designed for 3-4yr old children. Want to know what a space planet ACTUALLY looks like? You are on one now. earth. 

I played this game 4 years ago and i made a base built into the side of a mountain and it got 5k likes on reddit. That is all i am interested in doing again. and NO i do not want to play on boring relaxed mode.

But playing it once before does not make it easier to play again. Nor does it feel like its been updated since the last time i played (in regards to the start of the game) i am having all the exact same hangups as 4yrs ago.

i dont want to convert ferrite into pure ferrite, and then into magnetized ferrite, anymore. That was cool in the infancy of building games. But today it just seems like a sick joke.

 I no longer want to look for credit-tickets just to unlock a teleporter module. Maybe it was cool when building games were in their infancy. But now it just 100% sucks.

I hate buying a game like this then being asked what mode i want to play. Are you the developer or am i? Why cant you just have some relaxed planets and some challenging? Oh thats right because that would be too much work and the whole entire 19quintrillion planets are all controlled by a simple settings panel. Because every planet is the same. Just visually different.

If you were good developers you would start the player at a base already, with a great ship, generators in-place, everything working. Then you make quests that are close and easy, then you make quests further and further away. Then the player will naturally want to create a makeshift shelter

forcing the player to learn the whole entire game before you even give them a chance to kill something or explore, or swim, or do anything is just insane. How is it even possible to be that stupid? We dont even know wtf this is and you want us to learn TELEPORTERS AND POWER before even sampling the game? 

 The audacity of that is just incredible.

Nothing bothers me more than when a game has a tutorial before you can even get a chance to see if you enjoy it. The audacity of that. "oh hey before you even know if this is a good game, heres 8 hours of tutorial, oh and you are also dying instantly from radiation"

i still consider NMS the worst start of any game i ever experienced in 34 years of being alive

And the flying is awful, its like.. fake somehow?? I simply wanted to move my aircraft 10 feet closer to my base so i could transfer items to it. Lets just say i ended up 3 miles away from my base somehow. Worst flight controls i have ever experienced in 34 years of being alive. Its like flying a super unstable magnet or something

You cant just precisely fly around how you want to.. You have very little control over your aircraft. It has a mind of its own. Sometimes it wants to aim upwards at the heavens because it assumes you want to go to space

I thought for sure this game would have gotten at least slighly better in 4 years. Im sure all the new content is great but im having just as much trouble as getting into the game as i did 4 years ago

I find this to be incredibly boring and tedious more than anything. The vast world feels a lot of the same, each planet having most of the same or similar flora and fauna. Combat is easy and bland. The UI and menu navigation is a convoluted mess, as well as some of the quests being confusing to navigate.

The multiplayer is so throughout most of my experience me and my buddy barely interacted doing most our own thing. Only useful instance being to find easy planets to complete research. You can't build and base with each other which seems like a big point for multiplayer. Might as well play solo for anything that doesn't require multiplayer.

184176831.review:
Gameplay
No Man’s Sky is all about freedom. You want to explore endless planets? Go for it. Build a crazy base? Absolutely. Become a space trader, pirate, or just chill out and catalog alien creatures? It’s all there. The sheer variety of stuff to do is insane, and every time you think you’ve seen it all, you stumble across something completely new.

The survival mechanics are solid but not too punishing, which makes the game feel accessible. Gathering resources, upgrading your gear, and fine-tuning your ship is satisfying without being overwhelming. And the multiplayer? It’s a game-changer. Exploring the galaxy with friends adds a whole new layer of fun.

The Polished Experience
Waiting for the game to reach this polished state was 100% the right call. The updates—and there have been a lot of them—have added so much content. From base building and freighters to underwater exploration and massive expeditions, the game feels like it’s bursting at the seams. Plus, it runs like a dream now. No more buggy messes or awkward crashes—it’s smooth sailing (or flying, I guess).

Graphics and Art Style
Visually, the game is stunning. The art style leans into that sci-fi dream vibe with vibrant colors and surreal landscapes. Every planet feels unique, and the sense of scale is jaw-dropping. Whether you’re standing on a mountain watching the sunrise or zooming through an asteroid field, it’s pure eye candy.

Audio
The soundtrack is straight-up magical. It’s atmospheric, chill, and perfectly matches the sense of wonder the game is going for. The sound effects, like the hum of your ship’s engine or the alien wildlife’s calls, are top-notch. Together, the audio design pulls you deeper into this massive universe.

Pros and Cons
Pros:

Endless exploration and freedom.

Tons of updates that make the game feel fresh.

Stunning visuals and an incredible soundtrack.

Great multiplayer experience.

Polished and stable gameplay.

Cons:

The early grind for resources can feel a bit slow.

Some procedural planets can feel repetitive.

184153450.review:
No Man's Sky... What do I say about this game? First off, after its initial bombing, I'm suprised I even picked up this game in the first place. I think the first version I played was the PS4 one, when I was sick and needed something to stave off thinking about how awful I felt. I heard it was bad, but whatever, right? Well, what I got was certainly a nice little experience. Nothing as ground-breaking as its fans and developers like to think it is, but it certainly has a mystical air about it that keeps me coming back from time to time.

The first thing to realize about the game is that its core premise is a lie. No, no, don't leave, that's not a bad thing. Everything in this game tries to hammer home some idea of infinite exploration and discovery, but the thing is, once you've seen one planet of a certain biome, you've seen them all. The procedural generation can make the shapes of Stuff differ slightly, but it cannot change what is on what biomes, because game balance and progression dictates that certain things always be in certain places. Once you free yourself of the notion that the sandbox is infinite, then you become enlightened.

I think a truly important part of this game is making a little base on a nice planet and hanging out watching the sun rise. A person more clever than me once said that this game is a complicated sci-fi pulp novel cover generator, and I couldn't agree more. But it's not JUST that. I also really loved the plot (the Altas Rising one) and how it treated the world it made. It tells a touching tale of lonliness in a vast world, and ruminations on endings, something this game really made you feel via its gameplay... Well, until it added multiplayer. The developers are really good at ignoring the themes of the base game in favor of slapping more stuff into it. Anyways I wanted to say that it made me cry the first time I played through it. Great stuff.

Saying that, name any of the game's systems and I can tell you how weird and broken it is. Economy? Easy to game. Farming resources? Really hard until it becomes trivial. Combat? A pointless excersize in futility. Playing for the game mechanics itself may be a bit of a lost cause unless you really like jank.

I'm glad this game has apparently made so much money since it came out that the company making this can just add whatever they feel like to it without ever selling a second product. Not even a paid DLC. It's really something else. If nothing else, a unique experience that despite its many flaws I could never not give it a thumbs up.

184152444.review:
No Man's Sky – Ein Universum voller Möglichkeiten und Abenteuer

No Man's Sky ist eines dieser Spiele, die einen mit ihrer schieren Größe und Vielfalt regelrecht umhauen. Es gibt einfach so viel zu entdecken und zu tun, dass man oft gar nicht dazu kommt, den eigentlichen Plan umzusetzen – und genau das macht den Reiz aus! 🌌

Du wolltest nur kurz ein paar Ressourcen farmen? Zack, plötzlich entdeckst du eine seltsame Alien-Ruine, die dich auf ein Abenteuer schickt. Auf dem Weg dorthin stößt du auf ein exotisches Tier, das aussieht wie eine Mischung aus Giraffe und Käfer, und ehe du dich versiehst, bist du stundenlang mit Erkundung und Forschung beschäftigt.

Das Spiel fühlt sich wie ein endloser Sandkasten an, in dem du deinen eigenen Weg findest. Ob Basenbau, Handel, Kampf oder einfach nur die atemberaubenden Planetenlandschaften genießen – hier ist für jeden etwas dabei. Die Entwickler haben über die Jahre so viel Liebe reingesteckt, dass es heute kaum wiederzuerkennen ist. Jede neue Entdeckung fühlt sich an wie ein kleines Geschenk. 🎁

Natürlich ist nicht alles perfekt – manchmal fühlt sich der Grind etwas zäh an, und das Interface könnte an manchen Stellen übersichtlicher sein. Aber seien wir ehrlich: Wenn ein Spiel dich so sehr in seinen Bann zieht, dass du die Zeit vergisst, dann macht es ganz offensichtlich sehr viel richtig.

Fazit: Wenn du Lust auf ein Spiel hast, das dir das Gefühl gibt, ein echter Weltraum-Pionier zu sein, dann ist No Man’s Sky eine absolute Empfehlung. Sei bereit, dich in einem Universum zu verlieren, das größer und spannender ist, als du es dir vorstellen kannst. ⭐

Bewertung: 10 von 10 Planeten – und jeder davon einzigartig! 🚀

no mans sky famously launched in rough shape & slowly but surely redeemed itself in the eyes of fans/players after numerous large patches/updates brought the game into a state of respectability. despite this entire saga, i always felt mostly the same about NMS after playing it several different times at several different points in it's development cycle: it was a immersive, fun game with lots of exploration, but i wasn't as big of a fan of the base-building and resource management stuff, especially on higher difficulties. 

everyone wanted more of this game, but the devs have tried to make this game what we wanted it to be at launch and despite it taking many years of continuous content being added every few months, it really has become quite a fantastic game. the story leaves a LOT to be desired with quests devolving into a basic ass "go to x and interact with object" quest with like a sentence or two of lore given to the player through some mysterious transmission as a reward, only for it to happen again in a repetitive & uninteresting cycle that gets tedious far too quickly for what is such a expansive cool world/game.

184114085.review:
I wanted to leave this review because I fall a bit inbetween. Overall I can safely say I recommend this game, but it's not quite for me. I've been on the ride of this game since it came out and I am proud of hello games for turning it into what it is today. I just feel like what it has doesn't quite meet me where I want it to be. You can have fleets but they are only good for collecting and income based missions, same thing for settlements. You can build bases and collect resources for wealth but your impact on the market makes no difference other then a reduced selling point. It's cool to have these things set up, but I feel like I wanted to use them more ways then they are able. I found a lot of what I was looking for in X4 Foundations, which conceptually has some of these features, but they all have consequence in the total world. Fleets and move and patrol, attack others or block important points etc. A lot of the game gives me this feeling of having what I want in my space rpg type game, but never fully gives me that power. 

I think this game has a lot of great aspects to it though. If you want to be a space explorer and don't really care about anything above then stop here and know you've got a great game ahead. I haven't gotten to try VR yet but I'll jump right back into this game the moment I do. If you like to game to relax and see cool things this is a great casual experience to jump into. Also a great intro to space games which can be very intimidating. Also hello games just won't quit releasing new updates with large improvements. Even though I'm not currently playing I'm always looking at what work they're doing, it tempts me to reinstall every time. I hope they have success in further updates or other projects.

Rating: 10/10
No Man’s Sky is a game that truly amazes with its scale and endless possibilities. The procedurally generated worlds are stunning, and every planet feels unique. You can spend hours exploring, gathering resources, building bases, and simply enjoying the beauty of space.

What stands out the most is how the developers have continued to support and expand the game over the years. Each update adds incredible new features, like the multiplayer mode and the ability to establish your own settlements – perfect for playing with friends.

The graphics and atmosphere are breathtaking, and the music perfectly captures the vastness of space. If you love exploration, adventure, and creativity, No Man’s Sky is a must-play. Highly recommended!

184074071.review:
I was genuinely looking forward to enjoying No Man's Sky while vibing with friends in voice chat, even when some of us were playing different games. But to be muted for simply playing something else? That's an absolutely ridiculous rule. Playing other games in VC doesn’t discourage others from playing NMS—but being muted for it? That’s what’s truly discouraging.

Until this nonsensical policy is addressed, I’m not touching this game again. Not only that, but I’ll actively recommend my friends avoid it as well. If you want players to stay engaged, focus on making the game better—not treating every unrelated action as propaganda against it. This kind of behavior is counterproductive and disappointing.

184052009.review:
I bought this game on launch day back in 2016. I hoped for the same game most people hoped for, and although I enjoyed some aspects of it, I was ultimately left disappointed.

Fast forward to several years later when I started hearing about major updates and expeditions and other such things and I came back to find the game I originally wanted in 2016. There was variety, there was a story (multiple, really), there was interesting stuff to do. I was immediately drawn back in and played it for probably close to 100 hours before I set it aside again.

But what about now in 2024? Well, it's still being improved upon and it's still an expansive game that will provide you with many hours of content, especially if you like the idea of space exploration. Do yourself a favor and get this game and give it a shot. Unlike me in 2016, you won't be disappointed.

184047823.review: Gave this game a go back in 2023 when a friend recommended it to me. He showed me the basics, ins and outs of base building, freighter missions, and survival tactics. Safe to say I was drawn in to it's ultra-futuristic grab. The story can be a little slow to pick up on your first go as it has it's own learning curve to it but after you get the basics of surviving and building a base, it picks up rather quickly. There's so many different things to do in this game and many ways to play it. You can trade your way to resources or harvest/make them yourself, or just go for a walk on any of the quintillions of planets within countless star systems and get lost in the varying environments. One guarantee is that you'll never have two of the same play-throughs, and no man will ever live long enough to see all the skies have to offer.

184025799.review:
Space open world survival craft games are my favorite genre that is why I normally enjoy a lot of hours even when a game makes me wonder, do I have fun playing it. So I really really tried so hard to love this game, I gave it love by spending over 260 hours playing it with and tried so many different ways , new ways to go though my play, but every time I had to leave it at the bay, why? 

Here is why.
First thing first, the story or main quest. I found it boring because at first It appears very strong and interesting, but then I found myself just traveling from point to point, and do tedious grind to just jump to new places, then realized the story is kind of shallow, and it just want to create an excuse "a fake reason" for me to keep grinding and jumping to new systems. its also really bad that all new creatures and machines , when you harvest them, give up the same materials, its like only the look is different they all made from exactly same materials. 

Also dev made so much content overtime, but its basically the same old mechanics, only looks different, so what you do after 100 hour of game play is almost farming same old materials, mostly by hand, like the first 5th hours, I did not like that. 

I loved scavenging and repairing part of the game, to be able to find old broken abandoned ships on a planet and repair it, but that process also very very incontinent and they added more changes over time, which made it almost never worthy of you time to repair an old relic to life. 

perhaps the worst thing for me was the ship building, well it does not exists, simple. imagine in a  open world space game, there is no ship design. I mean customization. why? 

then again the side missions are super repetitive. all of these makes this universe to become boring after several hours, maybe the way to play this is to have several friends so you play together but for a single player campaign.

It make me sad to vote down to this game, its not a bad game, but it kind of disappointed me in several ways. sadly.

184022815.review: Everywhere I go, when I leave a planet or enter a system, a giant fleet of ships warp close to me with an incredible rumbling sound! I find this very annoying. There is nowhere to hide, nowhere to run in this vast universe from them! I simply wanted to relax in the game, find some peace, and explore amazing worlds, but this warping fleet ruined everything! This is extremely annoying and there is no way to get rid of it: I can't disable this feature or find a mod to fix it. NMS could have been one of my favorite games, but this huge fleet has spoiled everything. It's so disappointing...

184020243.review: Tutorial goes on for like 1 hour and a half, but after that the game lets you do what you want. Played it on console and etc, you pretty much do what the fuck you want which is great

184019938.review:
So overall this game is fantastic and fun. The developers have constantly attended to this game in various updates and patches, refreshing events for those that have missed them, and so on. I would most absolutely recommend this game to those that enjoy sci-fi titles and-or survival games. It combines them both really well with planetary survival and crafting to space combat and exploration. 

The only criticism I have of this game is the multiplayer aspect. When cruising with friends and we fight Sentinels or Pirates in space, there is a sync issue (which I hope one day gets fixed) where we're not exactly fighting the same capital/fighters ... We're not dealing damage to the same "structures" (like the turrets or engines) and it gets a bit wonky. As far as I can tell, the Derelict Freighter "Dungeons" seem to work okay though.

So yeah overall I give this game a **** (out of 5 stars), with the multiplayer bit being out of sync, and highly recommend this title (on sale or at full price, both are worth it) to anyone who loves a good space game!

184019431.review:
Le cœur du jeu est l'exploration de planètes et de systèmes stellaires uniques. Chaque planète possède des caractéristiques distinctes, de la faune à la géographie, créant un vaste univers à découvrir. Le système de ressources est profond, avec une gestion des matériaux et la recherche d'éléments rares.

Le jeu propose des graphismes magnifiques, avec des paysages variés et des effets lumineux impressionnants. L'ambiance sonore est immersive, avec des morceaux calmes et atmosphériques qui renforcent l'expérience.

Points forts :
Univers presque infini, offrant une grande liberté.
Exploration fluide, avec des vaisseaux et technologies variés.

Points faibles :
La répétitivité peut se faire sentir malgré la diversité.
Certaines planètes semblent vides ou peu intéressantes.

Note : 9/10

184008646.review: Brakuje mi tu odpowiedzi pośrednie między poleceniem lub nie poleceniem. mam mocno mieszane uczucia. Gra ma 8 lat i wg. wszystkich została bardzo poprawiona, rozbudowana itd. itp. Wierzę, bo pamietam jak była zjechana w dniach premiery i fakt, że aktualnie otrzymuje głownie rezcenzje pozytywne ale... Nie widzę w tej grze niczego wyjątkowego a widzę dużo...Takiej sobie gry o lataniu po kosmosie. jest połączeniem wszystkich innych gier które mam i w które gram, jak Elite Dangerous, Emyrion Galactoc Survival czy jakies tam inne kosmo survivalowo przygodowe. tylko, że w NMS wszystko jest mega urposzczone. niby mozesz zajmować sie wszystkim ale nic nie stanowi jakiegoś szczególnego wyzwania lub nie wymaga szczególnego wyspecjalizowania. Chcesz zostac "grónikiem" i pozyskiwac surowce z asteroid? Wystarczy, że bazowym statkiem w nie strzelasz. Chcesz robić eksploracje...Wystarczy, że pograsz jak ja, te 15h, odkryjesz technologie Warp i gotowe. Chcesz zajac sie handlem, grnduj, handluj, chcesz sobie zbudować bazę - buduj...Do tego masz kilka dodatkowych kosmicznych ras jak np. w Empiryon ale ich obecnosc nie ma jakiegos przemoznego wpływu na rozgrywkę. Do tego nadal gra ma troche pozostałych błedów jak zwierzaczki, które łazą bez sensu w kłko w powietrzu itp... Ok, w porównaniu do Elite Dangeorus NMS jest grą bardziej angazująca bo tu nie ma pustki typowej dla prawdziwego kosmosu (co też odbieram jako wadę) i podobnie jak ED niby mozesz sobie zbudowac statek ale nie jak w Empyrion, gdzie jego kształt i funkcje ogranciza tylko twoja wyobraźnia i dostęp do technologii i materiałów. Sa tu gotowe wzorce i wystarczy jest sklecic do kupy. nie zbudujesz tu niczego, co jest niepowtarzalne. i ostatecznie, mimo dodania jakiejś tam fabuły, watku zak tórym można podązać...po 15h jestem znudzony wciaz tymi samymi powtarzalnymi rodzajami minerałów, roślin, skał itp...Do tego wszystko w nieco cukeirkowej oprawie graficznej, przez którą nawet najbardziej surowe planety nie wyglądaja jakos szczególnie nieprzyjaźnie. Podsumowując....jak nie przychodzi ci do głowy żadna lepsza gra o lataniu po kosmosie...Kup NMS. Ale bądź swiadom, ze jesli szukasz wiecej dowolnosci, wyspecjalizowania w konkretnych gałęziach twojej działalnosci to...Sa gry do tego znacznie lepsze. A jak nie lubisz cukeirkowatej i czasem absurdalnej grafiki...To juz naprawdę poszukaj innego produktu.

The universe is wide, but almost nothing interesting happens in it and when it does, the same thing will happen time and time again, always the same way. So having played over 150+ hours, did I get my money's worth? Probably, though about half of that time was me going "is this all there is - there's got to be something more" - but there never was.

183944909.review:
Why I've fallen in love with NMS as I explained to another person:

I'm just finding cool planets. Like redacted planets, or armoured planets, or mutated planets where the filters all change and things look super unique. Or anomalous planets where reality warps as I'm walking around or a 'scalding rain storm' causes the temperature to plummet and bubbles to fall to the sky.

Maybe it's the years spent playing Freespace games when I grew up. Even though the flying and combat isn't quite as good or satisfying it still manages to scratch that itch of space combat.

Then there's the time spent fondly playing pokemon snap. Except now I'm going to planets and cataloging the xeno-biology.

The subnautica player in me loves free diving into oceans trying to find the new deepest depths. I spent so much time playing that game that spending time in alien oceans actually feels relaxing and enjoyable.

Some of it probably has to do with the economy management side of things and if I want to I can turn into a smuggler to turn big profits.

I also play a lot of survival crafting games, so the crafting system and progressing is just natural and feels right to me.

I've learned a good chunk of languages here, so in games where I can learn language (even though it just auto translates) I feel compelled to collect the knowledge to speak to the random Gek who's complaining that his food doesn't taste quite as good as it should.

Where else can I get pulled out of luminousity jump by a space worm with a giant eyeball and a rocket thruster up it's butt that spits an asteroid belt out at me when I shoot it?

I think for me NMS just scratches so many little itches that it cumulatively just tickles all the good spots in my brain. Sure the combat vs the sentinels can be a little tedious at times, and yeah... my colony citizens can be super needy. But it's so easy for me to overlook it.

And I STILL haven't gotten to exocraft, submersibles, living ships or dreadnaught capital ships!

183898526.review:
Overall this is a pretty good game that I think a lot of people would enjoy. I've had a bit of fun in it so far and the game offers quite a lot of things to do. 

Unfortunately if you are like me and you you like the feeling of some kind of progression or levelling system the game fails incredibly hard in that one aspect.

Enemies scale according to your ship and weapons instead of some other factor like distance to centre of the galaxy or traveller achievements. So if you upgrade your ship and fill it with stronger weapons, the combat actually gets harder. Enemies that used to get destroyed in 1 or 2 salvos, now take 3 or 4.

This means that there is literally no reason to change from your starting weapons and ship for the whole game unless you want to actively hurt yourself.

Another large negative is a few game breaking bugs. You will come across events occasionally where quests or POI will glitch out letting you get unlimited money or items. Sometimes you will come across main quest lines where if you did the quest in the wrong order you will be forced to wait for a daily reset to occur.

TLDR: You can see the developers have put a lot of work into this game but the focus is 99% of exploration, which leaves progression feeling flat.

183888929.review:
There’s so much wrong with this game, I don’t even know where to begin. It feels like a loose tech portfolio and inconsistent logic held together with duct tape.

(On PC and 4k display)

UI Mechanics: The UI is clumsy and overloaded with unnecessary animations, making even basic interactions tedious. In a game where inventory management is crucial, the UI design choices make no sense. Poor scaling options and wasted display space.

Economy System: Loopholes like endlessly producing valuable resources make trading and crafting pointless. Automation also feels unnecessary because manual gathering is faster and more efficient. Why bother with these mechanics when you can just "duplicate" and sell chlorine out of thin air? 

Galaxy Map: Accessing the star map is an absolute nightmare, with the GOAT worst navigation controls and a lack of system maps or detailed planetary information. Worse, it seems only accessible in space—when I plan a trip, I’d like to check the map *before* launching to space. Kinda makes sense, no? 

Missed Opportunities: The game’s crafting and chemistry systems mix sci-fi and real-world elements but miss the chance to use actual science. Why not stick to the periodic table and throw in a spectrometer? If players are to learn how to find and combine resources, why not teach real-world chemistry along the way?

Design vs. Bugs: While the game is technically polished and runs smoothly, its core design choices (UI, mechanics, systems) make for a frustrating experience. Aside from my first batch of chlorine (worth millions and hours of grinding) evaporating from my inventory and maybe a mislabeled button, I didn’t encounter bugs.

The game runs flawlessly at 60+ FPS @ 4K on an RTX 3060 with DLSS and high settings. It’s technically impressive, and respect is due for the ongoing updates, but the gameplay still sucks—by design.

183882982.review:
[h1]No Man's Sky[/h1]  Это игра, которая предлагает огромный, практически бесконечный мир для исследования, и с каждым обновлением она становится только лучше.

[h1]Что понравилось:[/h1]

- Масштабы и атмосфера. Ты путешествуешь по огромной галактике, исследуя уникальные планеты, флору, фауну и аномалии.

 - Свобода действий. Хочешь быть исследователем, торговцем, пиратом или строить базы? Выбор за тобой.

- Графика и саундтрек. Визуально игра завораживает, особенно закаты и космические полёты, а музыка добавляет глубины происходящему.

[h1]Что могло бы быть лучше:[/h1]

- Гринд. Иногда прогресс ощущается медленным, особенно если хочешь собрать редкие ресурсы.

- Разнообразие. Чем больше играешь, тем больше начинаешь замечать, что фауна, флора и даже планеты со временем начинают повторяться. В начале каждая новая локация удивляет, но через десятки часов эффект "вау" немного угасает.

- Оптимизация. На слабых ПК могут быть просадки FPS.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]

Несмотря на это, игра идеально подходит для тех, кто хочет расслабиться и насладиться бесконечным исследованием вселенной. Если вы любите космос, приключения и свободу выбора, No Man's Sky вас не разочарует.

Моя оценка: 🌌 8/10

183866376.review:
Because I'm not the kind of person who actually expects scantily-clad ladies to magically appear out of thin air every time I open a can of beer, I wasn't among the crowd bashing No Man's Sky when it first launched on PlayStation so many years ago. Though this game didn't live up to its pre-launch hype, nor did any other game released that year, or any year before or after. I still have no idea why players were so upset with Hello Games. Throughout the entirety of human history, there has not been a single product sold that didn't promise more than it could deliver. The person who invented the wheel no doubt claimed it could fly.

But even on launch day, despite its many shortcomings, No Man's Sky was great. It fulfilled what, to my mind, was its most important promise: an infinite alternate reality to explore on my own terms, with no objectives beyond the ones I set for myself. No missions, no quest, no main story. I could go anywhere and do anything, or go nowhere and do nothing. Just like in real life, the game simply didn't care. And it was glorious. Back then, No Man's Sky was something truly unique.

But then a bunch of brainwashed players started whining on and on about how the game "lacked content" and "needed a story" and "multiplayer" and so much other crap that the game absolutely did not need... 

During its initial development, Sean Murray had explicitly stated that this game would NEVER have quests. The game would never tell you what to do or where to go.

That's why I bought the game. That's the experience I wanted. And for a while, that's what it was. The irony is that if I had reviewed this game years ago, before all the crap that was added to placate the whiners, I would have given it a solid recommendation. Alas, that time is long gone.

For me, the only promised Hello Games truly broke was one that was broken well AFTER release: the promise of absolute freedom. 

I don't have a problem with this game getting a "main storyline" added on after release, but at the very least it should have been optional. It isn't. There's no way to cancel or remove the main quest - a nagging reminder of it is constantly displayed on the HUD.

So now No Man's Sky is no different from countless others out there - yet another "go there do that" game. Why do so many players need stories rammed down their throats? Why can't they just live their own?

This was a game I once truly enjoyed. Sadly, I can no longer recommend it.

183829479.review:
I pre-ordered the physical collector's edition of this game and as someone who has been a believer in this game from day one, let me tell you about it. This game is incredible. One of the most beautiful and relaxing games I've ever played. There is such an emptiness to space that feels almost terrifying, yet comforting. The hum of the engines, the glow of the dash, the sparkle of the stars, the soft rumble of the ship. It all comes together to paint a beautiful picture of serenity. There is so much excitement when landing on a new planet. Will I find the resources I need to fuel the ship? Will I get some new tech? Will I learn more about an ancient civilization? Or will pirates come out of the sky and attack me? There is never a dull moment. 

The stars are bright, but not as bright as the future was for this game. I still believe this game was not bad on release. It wasn't the best and it wasn't what was promised but I think, now, it far surpasses anyone's original expectations. Though I have to give respect to the amazing creators of this game. They made this their vision and more, they never let the community down. In a world with so much corporate greed and hatred, I thank you Hello Games and hope you have heard our collective apologies for our initial judgement. If only we could all be like No Man's Sky and become better versions of ourselves.

物語がひと段落ついた所でレビュー。セールで買って数年積んでいましたが、勿体なかった。革新的であるとも言い難いですが、そつなく宇宙の旅を楽しめる良作です。

宇宙探索系、世界構成は典型的。思想などが微妙にことなる種族が偏在して、その上位っぽい種族がいて、プレイヤーキャラはなんらかの理由でそこに近しい。デカいオブジェクトが都合のいいテキトーな哲学を語って狂言回し。ミッションは行ってこい持ってこいに終始。正直なところ物語全般は退屈。しかしながら、他のゲームやらで既知になっているから退屈なのであって、そんなネガティブな感情を抱くほどのものではありません。「いつものやつねー」ぐらいのテンションで処理を。

動作も軽快でUIも見やすく、快適に遊べます。ただ、時折カメラ位置が悪い。長い下り坂や海中の狭い場所で周囲を見渡すことが出来ないことが多々ある。惑星上での目的地表示も高低差の表現がちょっと直感的ではないらしく、自分の足元ぐらいに表示されているのに実際は山を三つ越えた谷底だったりします。ただ、ツッコミどころもそれぐらいしかないです。気に入れば長い時間をかけて遊べるのではないでしょうか。

なお、240割引で商品が売られているのが本作にみる「宇宙ヤバイ」のハイライトでした。しかも安くねえし。

NMS is the most beautiful and amazing game I have ever played, so far. Not only is there an endless line of missions you can do, each time I visit a planet I get so distracted from my original missions that I pick up at least 1 or 2 more just roaming around. The Flora is the most amazing part of the game for me, and the crazy animals each planet offers.

It's not boring, by far. It could never get boring to me, even collecting the same materials... You find new ones. I don't understand the negative reviews for this game, while everyone is entitled to their own opinion, some of them are posting lies all b/c they only played less than 10 hours of the game in total... Saying they just collected the same flora and fauna just to call it boring??? There are countless resources in this game that you can find, you just need to spend some time looking, which isn't boring at all when you consider how many times you are able to warp and how many planets there are to choose from.

Being able to spawn your ship, the anomaly, the space station and much more is very helpful. I love how easy it is to figure out the controls, it took some getting use to but we got there. The Paradise planets are my fav to visit, the glowing flowers keep me there for ages. My mission reminders keep popping up and I say, "OOOOOOOH YEAH SHIT!" XD The only thing I struggle with in this game is building my own base, I enabled the power so I don't have to connect it myself but even with that struggle, the custom settings make this game more fun than it already was to begin with. 

There are a lot of negative reviews for this game and since I checked them out, I can tell you that some of them are straight up lying so don't believe everything you read (As mentioned above). As far as having issues booting up, we never do. Our PC has issues from time to time so it does lag on lower settings but I don't blame the game for that. I'd recommend this game to anyone!

183790673.review:
It's a beautiful and mind bending game that explores the very meaning of existence. 

This isn't just some on the rails action rpg. Have patience and learn the game mechanics. You get to explore an infinite universe filled with planets with endless species of plants and animals to discover. Combine that with a massive variety of biomes and weather systems. Extreme storms, beautiful earth like paradises, barren worlds and worlds so bizarre that you're not sure whats alive and what isn't. 

There's Aquatic life. Underwater caverns. Volcanoes. 

Hidden mysteries to search out with everything from ancient extinct societies, abandoned ships, cosmic entities and so much more. 

There's trading and currency. 

Entire languages your character learns over time to begin to understand conversations with aliens. 

A mind bending main story that reaches deep into your emotions when faced with the question of what is existence.

BUT here's the best part. You don't have to do any of that. You can go build a base on a random planet or moon and seek out your own discoveries however you wish. Just give it a try. I've played most procedural universe games out there. 

There's nothing else like No Man's Sky.

I suspect they've built one of the best game engines out there behind the scenes, so I'm looking forward to seeing what else they can come up with... 

Overall - this game is amazing with gorgeous graphics, interesting systems, even a decent story now. It started as hot garbage, but the development team kept cranking out updates until it was a masterpiece. 

One of the few teams I would trust to see it through on a game.

183728737.review:
No Man’s Sky ist ein beeindruckendes Weltraum-Abenteuer, das sich über die Jahre enorm weiterentwickelt hat. Mit seiner prozedural generierten Galaxie bietet es eine unendliche Vielfalt an Planeten, die du erkunden kannst, jeder mit eigenen Ressourcen, Flora und Fauna. Das Erkunden, Ressourcen sammeln, Basen bauen und sogar der Handel bieten eine enorme Tiefe, die ständig neue Entdeckungen verspricht.

Was No Man’s Sky besonders macht, ist die kontinuierliche Verbesserung durch regelmäßige Updates – Multiplayer, neue Mechaniken und spannende Inhalte haben das Spiel von einem anfänglichen Mangel an Features zu einem echten Highlight gemacht. Die Grafik ist atemberaubend, und die Atmosphäre der verschiedenen Welten fühlt sich lebendig an.

Einziger kleiner Wermutstropfen ist, dass es nach einer Weile repetitiv wirken kann, wenn man sich zu sehr auf das Sammeln und Erforschen fokussiert, aber das tut dem Gesamterlebnis keinen großen Abbruch.

Insgesamt ist No Man’s Sky ein fantastisches Spiel für Fans von Weltraum-Exploration und Abenteuer, und ich gebe ihm eine verdiente 8,75/10 – eine fesselnde und ständig wachsende Erfahrung, die sich immer weiter steigert.

183715702.review:
No Man’s Sky es una experiencia única, especialmente si eres un jugador al que le gusta la supervivencia. Desde el momento en que comienzas, te encuentras en un universo que parece infinito, lleno de planetas por explorar, recursos que recolectar y secretos por descubrir. Personalmente, no he terminado el juego, pero he dedicado muchas horas a perderme en su vasto mundo, y siempre me queda esa sensación de que algún día lo terminaré. Hay algo fascinante en la libertad que ofrece y en cómo cada planeta que visitas tiene su propio carácter, aunque a veces las tareas se sientan un poco repetitivas.

Lo que más me atrae de No Man’s Sky es cómo logra mezclar la exploración con la supervivencia. La necesidad de gestionar recursos para mantener tu traje, tu nave o incluso para sobrevivir a climas extremos es algo que realmente hace que te sumerjas en el juego. Cada logro, por pequeño que sea, se siente como una victoria personal, y esa satisfacción es lo que me tiene enganchado. Hace mucho tiempo que un juego no lograba mantenerme tan involucrado como lo ha hecho este.

Eso sí, no es perfecto. Aunque el juego ha mejorado muchísimo desde su lanzamiento y tiene actualizaciones constantes que lo enriquecen, hay cosas que me sacan un poco de la experiencia. Por ejemplo, el lore del juego es tan disperso que a veces cuesta conectar con la historia. También echo en falta diálogos con voz, porque aunque los textos están bien escritos, siento que tener un poco más de vida en las interacciones con los NPCs haría que todo se sintiera más auténtico.

A pesar de esos detalles, no puedo negar que el juego tiene algo especial. Los paisajes, la música y la sensación de inmensidad son increíbles. Si eres como yo y disfrutas de la supervivencia y la exploración, este es un juego que definitivamente merece la pena. Es uno de esos títulos en los que puedes perderte por horas y seguir encontrando algo nuevo, incluso si nunca llegas a terminarlo del todo. Y quizás ahí está la magia: No Man’s Sky no se trata tanto de llegar al final, sino de disfrutar del viaje.

183715471.review: A fun game. Be a space pirate, be a trader, be a zoologist, miner, explorer, diver. There's a massive amount of base building options, customization, and most importantly; the space flight is fairly realistic without being tedious. 183696044.review:
Comecei minha jornada em No Man's Sky em um planeta peculiarmente hostil, onde a concentração de usuários de Twitter era tão alta que simplesmente atravessar o ambiente significava receber doses mortais de "radiação". A sobrevivência era prioridade, e eu corri desesperadamente até minha nave apenas para garantir que não viraria uma estátua de sal intergaláctica.

Logo que liberei o refinador, percebi que a ciência nem sempre precisa fazer sentido. Com um pouco de criatividade (e talvez violando algumas leis básicas da física), coloquei vários refinadores empilhados. Quando os quebrei, descobri que isso multiplicava itens. Desculpa, Newton, mas meu novo lema é: mais refinadores, mais lucro.

Com a nave consertada, dei meu primeiro salto no espaço. Menos de 30 minutos depois, encontrei um dos recursos mais valiosos: índio ativado. Coletei, multipliquei e vendi em um novo sistema, arruinando completamente a economia local. Repeti o processo até garantir que meu sistema natal fosse o mais próspero e invejado da galáxia. Capitalismo intergaláctico? Feito.

De volta ao meu planeta de origem, decidi que os habitantes locais precisavam de um toque pessoal. Capturei alguns usuários de Twitter (com nomes criativos como Xurrumino, Bambam e Dilma) e, para minha surpresa, todos pareciam mais grosseiros e feios que o normal. Naturalmente, eles se tornaram uma parte integral da "cultura" do meu planeta.

Explorando mais o universo, topei com um planeta infestado pelo que só pode ser descrito como o pesadelo de qualquer pessoa: baratas gigantes. Capturei uma delas e planejo fazer o melhor uso possível — entregá-las de presente para desavisados na Anomalia. Porque compartilhar é cuidar, certo?

Veredito Final:
No Man's Sky oferece uma experiência que é, no mínimo, única. Entre multiplicar recursos, ruir economias e criar um zoológico de aberrações, o jogo é um verdadeiro playground para mentes criativas e caóticas. Minha nota? Multiplicação/10.

183690501.review:
Título: "Um pequeno passo para o jogador, um Bug gigante para o jogo"

Entrei no jogo com um sonho: explorar o universo infinito, montar minha base, domar criaturas alienígenas fofinhas e ser um pirata espacial de respeito. Sai com outra coisa: um conhecimento profundo de como é ser sugado para o núcleo de um planeta por um buraco invisível.

O jogo te dá uma nave? Sim. Ela funciona? Depende do seu conceito de "funciona". Um dia eu estava tranquilo minerando um asteroide, no outro, minha nave decidiu que as leis da física eram opcionais e fui parar dentro de uma lua.

As criaturas alienígenas? Ah, incríveis. Já vi um cachorro que parecia um marshmallow com asas de borboleta. Chamei de Alfredo. Alfredo me abandonou porque aparentemente eu "não alimentava" ele direito. Desculpa, Alfredo, mas eu estava ocupado tentando entender por que meu jato propulsor só funciona quando eu fico de cabeça para baixo.

A comunidade? Incrível! Sempre tem um cara no chat global disposto a te ajudar.

No Man's Sky é como aquele amigo meio maluco que te convida pra uma aventura e você sabe que vai acabar se ferrando, mas vai rir o tempo todo.

Nota final: 10/10. Jogo ruim? Nem. Jogo perfeito? Também não. É o caos controlado do jeito que a vida no espaço deve ser. Recomendo. 👽✨

183661465.review:
I honestly tried giving this a chance. I played as long as could, unlocked all content that I could, did expeditions and everything that the game could offer. In the end, I just found that this game to be a chore to play and extremely shallow. The biggest problem for me personally is the UX of the game and how it just constantly interrupts the gameplay with the message screens and take the control away from you. 
It is also clearly obvious that everything in the game is procedurally generated. All planets are essentially the same with some  of them being a bit more different from the rest. Essentially you get a mountain hot planet, a mountain cold planet, a mountain wet planet, a mountain planet partially filled with water, a mountain barren planet and on occasion you will see a somewhat more level planet or the planet that has more water than land. You will get the same variation of the animals throughout the game, again with some exceptions they are just Earth animals with different skins on top of them. You get flying cow, swimming cow, flying dog, swimming dog, green colored dog, blue colored dog, land octopus, water octopus, some dinosaurs, and so on. There are indeed some unique and interesting flora and fauna in the game, but those are very rare. And most of the activity is rediscovering iron under a different name in each planet. 
There also these stupid planetary storms every few minutes that basically prevent you from properly playing the game. Every darn time you try to land on planet, there is a storm that makes you unable to see anything until you right above the ground. 

Don't get me wrong, there is a lot of potential in this game and there is a lot that you could do - build and collect ships, build the base, explore some unique planets, collect unique items, etc. The most complete and interesting activity in this game is the base building and if you want a cool base building game and like spending a lot of time on it, then this game is definitely for you. However, the game butchers all of these activities as the only thing you can persistently do is the base building. You cannot actually collect ships or items as many of them are treated more like a game mechanic and not an item. As in you cannot put them away or display and they just get unlocked and appear in your menu as a choice when they do.

When you play this game without a break, it does sort of suck you in with visuals and other experience, but like I mentioned before, I would be constantly pulled back by a bad UX design that would block your screen all the time and take control away. Some other game mechanics are kind of fine, but also aren't that great. Even the jetpack is not fun and is very mediocre here. Your character also cannot jump and is reliant on the jetpack for this. It leads to some of the design choice that contradict each other (in particular when you explore the wrecked freighters). 

All in all, I was playing it for a while and then took a break for 2 or 3 days and found that I simply cannot make myself launch this game again. I would play literally anything else, but not this game. It's just too repetitive and too much of a chore-like game. It needs to have a lot more and deeper mechanics that are actually integrated together and not just exists in a vacuum independent of each other.

No Man's Sky: The Ultimate Space Glow-Up

When No Man’s Sky launched, it felt like getting a spaceship with no fuel and a manual written in alien hieroglyphs. The galaxy was vast but emptier than my fridge on payday. Fast forward to now, and it’s like Hello Games said, “Hold my warp cell,” and turned it into the coolest intergalactic theme park ever.

Base building? Check. Space whales? Check. Sentient ships and underwater palaces? Double check. They didn’t just fix the game—they added so much content, I half expect the next update to include a space taco truck. Every patch feels like Christmas morning, and Sean Murray must have unlocked the cheat code for infinite productivity.

Now, No Man’s Sky is a universe packed with friends, weird alien pets, and bases that look like Elon Musk’s fever dreams. It’s gone from "meh" to "must-play," and honestly, if you’re not exploring it yet, what are you doing? Stop reading this and go build a space empire, already! 🚀

183610718.review:
They've done it. This is the original turn-round story.
From a historic failure at launch to nearly a decade of free updates the size of expansions, the state No Man's Sky is in today is nothing compared to what it was at launch. This is indeed a good and addicting game.
Constantly, I find myself asking "What's over there?" when I am on a planet, and when I am in space I ask "What will I see on that planet?"
Once I get in a play session, I find it hard to stop playing, as there is a constant desire to expand and exploit the universe for the resources needed to empower my Traveller, grow my base, see more of the world, and meet new aliens.

It is, however, not without flaws, but nearly all of these flaws can easily be overlooked due to the scope (and fun!) of the game itself.
The controls are not great, and the key rebinding leaves a lot to be desired. The scanner scope feels like it should be a toggle, but there is no accessibility option to make it a toggle. Your multi-tool will quickly be filled with functions and weapons and there is only one key to cycle forward through them (not even backwards!). Ideally it would be nice to have either a weapon wheel or even better, map the different multitool functions to a hot key - sadly, this cannot be done, making switching quite clunky.
The ship also never feels as responsive as I would hope for. There are 2 control schemes in the options, but the default option feels like driving while drunk as the ships glides and overshoots your target, while the second control scheme makes it feel like driving while you are tweaking out from a caffeine overdose as it jitters around your target.
Eventually planets do start to feel a little bit samey in so far as the resources and types of buildings you find. While the resources may look different, they almost always award the same type of materials. While planets will have their own specialty resources, the common rocks, trees, and even weird floating alien mushroom rocks all award ferrite or carbon or oxygen. And every planet seems to have it's own fauna, as well as random ships flying through the atmosphere, and various buildings of similar types. It never feels like I am a lone explorer on a desolate planet. The universe is almost too alive now.

But, as I said at the top of this review, none of this really detracts from the enjoyment I am having. This is a good game, and if you'll give Sean Murry and Hello Games a second chance, I think they will have more than corrected the mistakes of long ago, all for a single price tag, a great and well loved game.

183607191.review:
Honest review from a guy who love space exploration/trading/base building/empire expanding games.
I am going to skip over alot of redundant features in this review.

First 15 hours of No Man's Sky, outside of the super sluggish tutorial, was a blast.
It was insanely fun exploring and seeing new stuff like randomly generated settlements on planets and such.
I was hooked and played it in one sitting.
After those hours are up, you start to realize, "Wait I've done this like 3 or 4 times now I keep getting the same missions, events, pirate attacks, planet outposts and exploration curiosities, with the same rewards."
And after a few hours of the same repeating you start to feel like you've seen the entire game.

Most of the things in this game honestly save no purpose.
You can get an auto miner or oxygen harvester, but why would you? You can hold down E over some glowy mushrooms and get enough oxygen for the next 10 hours of gameplay, or mine 1 or 2 nodes of whatever material and have enough for 10 hours. Or alternatively, just buy it off the market, where resources cost nothing and you will never run out of money.

Base building serves zero purpose outside of aestethics.
Taming animals seemed to serve zero purpose, nothing in this game seemed to require anything from animals.
There are like 10 missions which all are extremely boring:
example: kill 10 things, kill a pirate, scan minerals.
Killing 10 things is extremely trivial as nothing in this game except for sentinels (totally avoidable) even fights back.
You can just stand on a rock and mining beam anything to death.
Space combat is EXTREMELY one dimensional. You hold down the hotkey S which activates auto-pathing auto-follow auto-dogfight mode and then press mouse 1 once your crosshair happens to line up with the enemy.
There is no fear of death as you can infinitely recharge your shields INSTANTLY with a resource you get in abundance as soon as the game starts.

My last gripe is the so called "space anomaly". It's a death start ball thing you spawn where you can basically invalidate any progression mission they put in the game because you can buy like every upgrade directly.
Honestly not a bad thing considering how tedious and repetetive these "technology unlock" missions were anyway.

Lastly I appreciate what Hello Games did and are still improving the game, but at this point idk what could save this game, it just has so much content but very little of it is meaningful.
A good saying is "wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle".
And this is coming from someone with nearly 400hours on elite dangerous, a game that is infamous for this.

TLDR: You see 98% of the game in 15 hours and after that it's up to you how much you want to repeat what you saw in those 15 hours.

183601445.review:
Ну как вам сказать...No Man's Sky -  чертовски обворожительная и очишуенно прекрасная игра!
Первое , что хочу написать - в этой игре 18, Карл, квинтиллионов планет!
Большинство читающих этот обзор ,я уверен, не знают даже как выглядит это число, как и я не знал пока не загуглил. Выглядит это так:
Это число с 18 нулями (1 000 000 000 000 000 000 = 10(18), тысяча квадриллионов или миллион триллионов)!
И каждая из этих планет процедурно генерируемая, отличающаяся от остальных, за то время которое я успел поиграть до написания этого обзора я нашел лишь одну звездную систему, в которой первооткрывателем был не я.
В этой игре ты можешь выживать, строить базу(некоторые игроки тут строят, черт побери, произведения исскуства!), исследовать новые планеты, искать новые виды животных, заниматься сельским хозяйством,сбором ресурсов, торговлей, строительством своего огромного корабля, даже с друзьями по сети можно поиграть...черт, перечислять можно очень долго, но поверь - возможностей куча!
Проиграв в эту прекрасную игру на данный момент чуть больше 60 часов я столкнулся с тем , что хочется заняться всем и сразу - и найти себе уютное райское место для базы,и исследовать грузовое судно чтобы расширить его , и просто поискать красивых животных(которых кстати можно приручать),и еще кучу всего!
Иногда я тратил на исследование одной только планеты по два или три часа, потому на ней было что то интересное и красивое.
Без преувеличения, в этой игре можно провести сотни, а может даже пару тысяч часов, переодически вновь возвращаясь и играя в нее.
Моя оценка этой игре - 10/10, лучшая игра в этой тематике на данный момент.По всем критериям.Графика , музыкальное сопровождение, геймплей, контент, сюжет - 10/10!
Шон Мюррей , мужик, если ты это читаешь - СПАСИБО ТЕБЕ!
Так же спасибо всей команде Hello Games, вы - красавчики!
Обязательно дополню этот обзор спустя несколько лет или сотен наигранных часов, ведь игру постоянно обновляют и дорабатывают, слышал что с 2016 года она стала, как говорят, совершенно другой и не разочаровала комьюнити!

183594093.review:
I love this game overall and have since I first started playing it in, I believe it was 2018. Despite that however, I do still have issues with it..issues that have existed for YEARS. Things like:

- Clipping issues when you're trying to place items (IE: posters going behind walls).
- Clipping issues from wildlife. They have a tendency to walk right through your base's walls.
- Characters spawning through the floor, which isn't just a visual glitch but also prevents you from talking to them. This can be really annoying if talking to one of said characters is required to finish a quest. Restarting the game is the only way I've found to remedy that.
- Upgrades on your exosuit and multipool randomly disappearing (specifically the upgrades that need to be recharged). Restarting the game is required.
- Weapons on certain exocraft (in my case the rover) simply stop working. When this happened I had to actually destroy and re-install the weapon.
- Marked waypoints on your visor will randomly disappear at times.
- Terrain and vegetation will re-grow through your base's floors and walls.
- Illumination from light fixtures is TERRIBLE. You sometimes wouldn't even know they're even on unless you're looking right at them, which kind of defeats the purpose of installing lights.
- Many times when moving items (especially light fixtures), they'll randomly turn sideways and upside down instead of their default or current position requiring you to either painstakingly turn the thing through 4 axis to correct it or to just say "screw it", delete the item, and re-build it.
- No basic search function OR ability to sort items alphabetically in catalogue, making finding certain recipes and what-not way more of a hassle than it should be.
- You can't edit your main starship's appearance (not even the freaking color)...yet you can with your freighter.

   I'm sure there are more things I could add to this list, but I think it's gone on long enough. Hello Games has done a magnificent job over the years with adding content, but they certainly have work to do when it comes to bugs and quality-of-life improvements.

183565795.review:
I skipped this game during its disastrous launch 8 years ago, but after years of updates, it’s now a lot of fun. That said, some core design issues remain. After visiting about 20 planets, you’ll realize you’ve essentially seen 95% of them, except for the rare, unique ones. If pure exploration is your main goal, this might not be the game for you.

Personally, I’m not big on exploration games. What kept me hooked were the other aspects: hunting for ships, chasing small weapon upgrades, and uncovering bits of story. On a technical level, the game is brilliant. There’s essentially no loading screen—just seamless transitions between planets, which feels amazing. The only noticeable loading happens between solar systems, but even that’s so well-designed it doesn’t feel like a loading screen. My one gripe is the short draw distance for some details like plants and buildings, which can break immersion.

The combat is hit-or-miss. On-foot combat is just okay—nothing special. Space combat, on the other hand, is tough unless you use auto-tracking. But the game feels balanced around auto-tracking, which makes it functional but a bit dull.

Seasonal expeditions are a great touch, giving you reasons to come back and unlock cool cosmetics, which I’ll definitely be doing.

Overall, No Man’s Sky isn’t for everyone, but I’ve really enjoyed what it has to offer. It also feels like this might be great VR title, but I don't have the headset to test it.

183561609.review:
Breadth and simplicity are the strengths of No Man's Sky. Accusations of being wide but not deep are true. It's a game that lets you do almost anything a space-exploration game should, in a simple, arcadey way. While there is combat and threat, No Man's Sky is mostly easy-going and relaxing. It's not for the simulationist, but perhaps for the completionist.

No Man's Sky is a game that offers frequent changes of pace. Explore and catalog for as long is it's fun, then hunt and kill for as long as that's fun, then manage your small fleet and send them on missions, then go quest through the game's story. Look for different starships and parts, learn alien languages, collect and trade, build bases, chase bounties or engage in piracy. Pilot ships and mechs and land vehicles and submarines if you like.

None of No Man's Sky's systems have the kind of depth that calls for spreadsheets or wikis. Being straightforward and accessible works to its advantage, if that's your speed.

No Man's Sky offers a big wide world that I'm always happy to dive back into, which welcomes me back in kind. A world that, through variety, never gets boring.

183559372.review:
A sztori részt nem vittem ki. Alapvetően ilyen jellegű játékoknál nem is az az elsődleges priorítás részemről.
Kb. 156 óra játék után elmondhatom, hogy hangulatos játék; látványra nem rossz, viszont lehetne jobb is. 
A plusz pozitívumot elmondom így az elején, hogy a fejlesztők folyamatosan bővítik a játékot!

Pró:
- Megszámlálhatatlan mennyiségű naprendszer és bolygó. (Legyen elég üzemanyagod a hiper- és a sima hajtóművekhez :D )
- Nagyon open-world. A bolygókon sétálgathatsz, repülhetsz, amennyit akarsz.
- Számos faj, és interaktálhatsz, kereskedhetsz velük. Küldetéseket csinálhatsz nekik, ezáltal a befolyásodat növelheted náluk.
- Különféle járművek. (Teherhajó -vagy inkább zászlóshajó-, magán űrjármű, földi- és vízi járművek).
- Multitool. Ami tényleg az. Még horgászhatsz is vele. Egy svájci bicska hozzáképest kispályás eszköz. :D 
- Minden is fejleszthető (űrruha, járművek).
- Változatos nyersanyagok és azokból készíthető produktumok, vagy más nyersanyagok.
- Bolygók élővilága, környezete, éghajlata különbözik. Eddig kb. 1x találtam még egyszer ugyanazon élőlényt két különböző bolygón. Viszont van, ahol élőlény sincs. 
- Bázis építés.

Kontra:
- Néhanapján (mikor komolyabb bázist szeretnél -a 4 fal + 1 tetőn kívül- építeni) a bázisépítés egy agysebészet. Pl. a lépcsők elhelyezése. Ha ehhez van türelmed, akkor mindenhez is van.
- Sok bolygó van ugyan, de az alapanyagok palettája nagyon szűk skálájú. Tehát az összes bolygón ezeket lehet megtalálni, csak van amiből több van vagy kevesebb. Így a bolygók nem igazán egyediek a környezetet vagy élővilágot, éghajlatot leszámítva.
- Ellenség diverzitása. Eddig egy kezemen meg lehet számolni, hogy mennyi ellenség van, ebből egy fix. A többivel meg lehet barátkozni is.
- Számos hajótípus megtalálható, illetve lehet saját űrhajót is létrehozni. De mindezek ellenére mindegyik jármű belseje ugyanaz...Maximum statisztikában különböznek, meg formára, kinézetre, belsőleg sajnos ugyanaz.
- Űrharc enyhén szólva egyszerű, és így sajnos monoton. "S" betűt nyomod, majd célra áll a hajód és lőnöd kell.

A fentiek alapján azért ajánlom, mert tényleg bárki eltud benne lenni. Az is aki sztorizni szeretne, illetve az is aki csak "chillezni", vagy aki mindkettőt szeretné. :D

Köszi, hogy elolvastad.

183548707.review:
I deeply regret buying this game. The premise is nice, the game tries to combine different genres and fails to make this work.
The tutorial is a mess. One starts in survival mode and is constantly in fear of dying. That would be OK, if this was a survival game but it is not after some time. The whole UI and controls are a bit clunky and overwhelming. And the stress of the tutorial makes it difficult to ensure one gets all the information one needs from the tutorial.
After that, it becomes better and a bit more intersting, but leads to nothing.
This is an exploration game, where exploring quickly becomes boring. It is unclear what one should do, the tutorial and early missions seem to be pointless, and even worse: do not really engange and become quickly boring chores.
The whole gameplay is repetitive, in many cases unnecessarily, and is not really rewarding. Even after a few hours everything is a mess.
Many actions in this game have to be done repetitively, and become boring. One wonders around, wondering what to do, and suddenly gets engaged by an enemy and dies. Why do base building, where does it lead to?
Why explore, after a few hours there is not really anything new, why play this game.
And worst of all: it never triggers satisfaction or well being for me. Even on easy mode, I still constantly fear to do something wrong, miss something, or just die because...

This game does nothing right.
